column3: Very beautiful city (especially at night) though quite hot, we were walking around in 40 degree heat. Not a particular problem ... just walk slowly. Very easy to get lost (and shade) in streets as it's like a maze. We grabbed a free map and it felt very safe wandering. Well worth checking out for two or three days.

Not much to dislike other than time passing too quickly and not being able to take in everything in the time we were there. To be able to park centrally for free and see most of what you want by foot is a real bonus too...

This was a long long trip but well worth it what a beautiful place it is. We went shopping but passed through tower of Gold Maria Louisa park and had a stop at the plazza of Spain if you wanted to you could visit the Jewish quarter of Santa Cruz. shops were good too but as usual watch what u buy I went into the Super dry store and came out with nothing as it looked like cheap rubbish It cost us only 20 euros each and that was booked through the ticket shop The other booking office is the Algarve experience in the old town but not recommended as they are really expensive Taking a trip book through the ticket shop Will save you loads of money and they have specials on as well This trip too long for children though

Seville is a lovely city with many beautiful buildings. The cathedral is right in the middle of a shopping street and stands very majestic. The palace is nearby. It is a lovely city to wander around with many architectural wonders. There are also plenty of eating places and shops. A trip down the river gives another perspective. Well worth a visit.

Seville is a great place with lots of hidden cafes and attractionsPublic transport is easy to use and plenty on offer, you must use a city map which makes things easier and don't be tempted for free offers as there is no such thing everything costs in this cityHave been to other locations in Spain and with 7 million people who live in this city its not the cleanest so be prepared to see some rubbish in the streetsThere seems to be a large police presence so we did feel safe

Sevilla is charming, interesting and a great place to visit. Be prepared to get lost on its winding streets. We spent 4 days here and thought it a good amount of time. We would happily return; there is much to see and do in Sevilla. Cross the bridge to Triana; the feel is much different. On Sundays, artists sell their work along the river - not a huge number of artists, but a very enjoyable way to see the river and interact with local people. A carriage ride is worthwhile, as is a visit to a tapas bar. Plaza de Espana is incredible, as is the Alcazar. Eat chirros and drink cocoa!

We spent 3 days in Seville and you can see most attractions and get a taste for the place in that time. A very vibrant cit and lovely to see the Spanish families out together on a weekend. Saw of couple of stag and hen parties but nothing like those in England where everyone is falling over drunk, these were just having fun. The tapas bars were the best we've ever experienced. I'd give the cathedral a miss but did enjoy the Museum of Fine Arts and a very strange look around the Casa Palacio de la Condesa de Lebrija. This palace house a very varied collection of antiquities built up over her life time. Roman mosaic floors, delft plates even hung on the ceilings and anything else shew could buy between 1901 and 1913.

Very nice and pretty city you must see. Actually Seville has a very important historical role into Spanish (and Europe) mile stones. It’s one of that city you can visit by walk because lot of attractions are concentrated in the city center. There’s one of the most important university in Europe, so there’s a lot of people around. Very good for relaxing visiting and party as well: lot of bars and restaurants. Be back for sure.

Sevilla has it all; architecture, culture, flamenco, parks, bars, beautiful weather, tapas, etc, etc. I have seen all major cities in Spain and Sevilla beats all of them....easily. Take 3-4 days at least, but you can also stay 1 week. No problem.

I was in Seville 2 days ago and I can never get tired of seeing the city and all the splendor in it. Getting to Seville via train from Malaga was a trip in itself. The 2hrs 30 min train ride was actually not all that bad. You get off in Seville Santa Justa and you need to take the C1 bus to get into the city center. You can catch the bus from the main road right in front of the train station. (When you come outside the station, there is a taxi stand. Walk right pass that and you will see a bus stop across the lot. The C2 bus is on the same side of the street as the station while you need to cross the street to catch the C1 bus) The C1 bus gets you into the city faster. The C2 bus gets you to the train station faster. There is an Infomation booth for tourist inside the train station and you can pick up a MAP from there. There is a Hop on Hop off bus you can buy tickets from over there as well. You buy the bus ticket on the bus when you get on. Know in advance where you need to get off and with a MAP in hand, you can find your way to your hotel. The Cathedral, Giralda tower, Alcazar castel, Torre del Oro, Macarena Walls and Church, Pillar of Hercules etc... its ALL good. Enjoy the small side street and the Arab influence in this majestic city of Seville.

Generally I prefer to review establishments and attractions within a city rather than the city itself. But Sevilla is special. Almost everything is within walking distance, it's easy to find good food and entertainment, shopping is abundant, the hotels are conveniently located and the sights to see are spectacular. But beyond that Sevilla is just a pleasant place to spend time, to walk the gardens and narrow streets.Sevilla and Barcelona vie for our favorite large cities in Spain. One can't go wrong in either.
I knew nothing before going and was really impressed with the culture, nightlife, food, and art of sevilla. I could have easily spent weeks there.
Seville is easily enjoyed on foot - its easy to get lost but half the fun. Lots of different things to see. Even all the shops with the clothes and accessories for the bullfights were interesting.

Four days of sunshine exploring the area of Santa Cruz, Alcazar and Plaza de Espana, whats not to like. We enjoyed the whole buzz of the city, bars, tapas and restaurants. Travelling in March also meant kind weather, warm sunny days and cool evenings and the scent of the orange blossom was everywhere. Wonderful

We spent 5 days hanging out visiting and exploring this beautiful city while visiting our daughter who is spending a semester abroad here. It is a lovely place and it is such fun to settle into an apartment and have the time to relax and explore at our leisure. We stayed just adjacent to Barrio Santa Cruz which was absolutely perfect! Enjoy!
What a nice change from Madrid. Seville is a little more manageable that the larger Madrid. It has one of the best restaurants in Spain called Abades Triana.
Very accessible - everything within walking distance. Orange trees everywhere! The Alcazar palace was amazing but we also loved the little alleyways and shops.

So many things to see here. We rented an apartment for a week (SpainSelect, Mates Gago) and cannot recommend Sevilla enough. From the Real Alcazar, Cathedral, Flamenco, Shopping, & Cafes, we had a grand time. While we often target specific attractions for where we go in Spain, after spending such a great week here, we intend to return just to hang out and relax in the best big city with small town atmosphere.
Alcazar, House of Pilatos, Cathedral, Flamenco, all the narrow streets, friendly peopleI would not recommend the Flamenco Museum. Was a disappointment.

column2: “Beautiful historical city with plenty to do and see. Factor in lots of bar and cafe shops to ease the amount of walking”
column3: Ancient city with loads of history and culture. Clean and neat.Eating out is generally inexpensive. This is tapas city-- do try a bit of everything.Try and pop into tapas places where the locals mostly are as they are happy to see you and talk with you. The Sevillians are friendly, courteous and passionate about their culture and food .Soft drinks can be more or as expensive as wine and beer. Cafes serve great coffees and cake.There are jasmine trees everywhere and mixed with orange blossoms the fragrance is beautiful .Go to favourite sights ( like Alcazer) early in the morning and if that's not possible try between 12- 2pm when the crowds (especially the tour groups) lessen !This is not a city that should be rushed - it has to be enjoyed for its sublimeness.You will need to have a good sense of direction or navigational skills as there are many side streets not marked on maps and you could be walking further than you intended.I used two maps to get a range of marked streets. Having said that it's not that difficult to get around.In some ways it's lovely to get lost as there are many surprises ( beautiful balconies, doors, house, locals etc ) in the less trodden alleyways. Santa Cruz area is perfect for wandering around!A pair of good cushioned footwear is highly recommended due to cobbles and the amount of walking to be done.This is a city that benefits from walking around.Some shops shut for siesta so be aware if you've planned for some shopping. Good shopping to be had.Stay out late like the locals and enjoy the late night shows and bars. It is not rowdy or raucous- hen and stag parties haven't descended into Seville so the whole scene here is still tame and classy.

We rented an apartment in Seville for 2 months. We walked everyday until we explored beyond the must-see sights; we had time to immerse ourselves completely in its culture, to really understand its history, its art, architecture, food, music, its style..it was a real privilege to have had the opportunity to do so. We travelled further afield to Malaga, Cordoba, Granda, Cormona, Cadiz, Jerez, Santiponce and Sanlucer. We used the reliable train service, no need to drive anywhere, especially here in Seville. We arrived in February, the weather was mild, the city was very quiet with few tourists but everything changed in March; the sun shone and the tourists arrived by their thousands and out of the woodwork came with the inevitable opportunistic street beggars...just to let you know, we saw the same group everyday around 12 of them, weekends they became heavy handed in their approach; some would thrust a rosemary cutting directly into the hand or even into the face of an unsuspecting tourist, while others would simply sit with holding a plastic cup by the Cathedral entrance; others would hassle you as you sat outside a cafe or even inside; some would pretend to 'play' an instrument, not a tune just an assortment of notes the hope you'll hand over your money, please don't. I'm pleased to say that this very small band of thieves did not succeed in influencing our opinion of this extraoridinarily beautiful city, so don't let them put you off, they are few and there is an international hand gesture that never fails. We're off to spend a month in Venice, we just hoped we haven't peaked too early.

Seville is without doubt my favourite Spanish City and one of my favourite cities in the world. It's the perfect place to leave your car parked and to just roam around for 3 to 4 days soaking up the wonderful Andalusian atmosphere. The magnificent architecture and monuments, the mouth-watering food, tapas and wines together with the general feeling of abandonment make Seville an idyllic place to spend time in. My last stay was at a charming bouique hotel in the most scenic Santa Cruz district, the El Rey Moro, a stone's through from the city's main sites. Of course the must see places are without doubt the Cathedral and Giralda tower, the Alcazares Reales, the Plaza de Toro, the Ayuntamiento and Plaza de Espana. However, I highly recommend just walking around the streets and alleys and getting lost in the backstreets to discover your own Seville. Also if you cross the Isabel II bridge to the Triana district there are some restaurants on the broadwalk offering a picturesque view over the river towards the city centre. I have now been to Seville 4 times but will surely be back again one day.

Sevilla is delightful and we were pleasantly surprised at the value for money offered in their variety of eating places. We had the set lunch during the day and sampled a variety of Tapas at night. If you go, highly recommende, take a compass with you. The maps and streets can be pretty confusing.

The people were so warm and welcoming. Our tour guide was David from Not Just a Tourist. He was very educated on the area and he made sure our experience was local and not touristyHe went over and above our expectations. He drove us to Granda and showed us other areas

worth touring these cities absolutely beautiful. the Alhambra in Granada takes some beating but Cordoba Seville and Jerez are not far behind especially if like Moorish gardens. and as for historic buildings hard to imagine anywhere better. if your a pensioner take your passport its cheaper.
Loved the historic buildings, the palaces, the Cathdral, and the authentic tapas bars and flamenco bars.The locals couldnt all speak English but were always very friendly and hospitable

Seville was the highlight of a recent trip to Spain that included Madrid, Seville, Granada and Arcos de la Frontera. Stay in the old part of town, in or near the Barrio Santa Cruz, if you can. All the sights are within easy walking distance. Download Tripadvisor's Seville City Guide which is very helpful and which works off line so you don't use incur expense for data usage. The sights are wonderful, including Plaza de Espana, The Alcazar, The Cathedral, but what makes it great is just the overall ambience of the place. For the most part, the people are friendly and warm, and they seem to have a great outlook on life. Walk by any tapas bar in the evening and you'll see the locals enjoying themselves and relaxing. Take in a Flamenco show, enjoy churros and chocolate and simply unwind. I can't wait to go back!
A beautiful City especially the areas of the Cathedral, Alcazar and the old Jewish area. Winding streets, little shops and cafés. We were not impressed by the Red Bus tour.A trip to remember.

column2: “One of the most beautfuk cities in the world”
column3: It's safe and beautiful. If you find the right bars off the beaten track, you will enjoy great tapas and good local beer and wine at a really good price. I lived here 24 years ago as a student and this city has a huge heart that will beat forever and ever in your heart !!! You MUST visit Seville.

I'm not quite sure what I expected when visiting Seville, what I found however was an amazing city with I think, something for everyone. We visited the cathedral, the Alcazar and Plaza de Espana, went to a number of bars/restaurants, of which there seem to be thousands, walked miles and miles around the shops of which there also seem to be thousands and generally had a really nice time! We drove to Seville from Malaga, a really easy drive of about 2 hours but once we got to the city the parking could have been a nightmare with some carparks charging nearly 100€ for 24 hours parking. We decided to be brave/foolhardy and parked the car on the street. We left it for 3 days and it was still there when we returned, no tickets or clamps or anything! Cars are parked anywhere and everywhere it seems.If visiting this beautiful and lived in city you will need plenty of energy as the combination of the walking and the heat(even in March) is tiring...great excuse for a siesta!

This is Spain as Spain should be: the shops sell Flamenco dresses and shoes and, whilst I was there, they were practising for the Holy Week processions. The whole place is full of orange trees and the Cathedral is awesome. Seville is, however, an expensive town: beware!
It's warm, it has attractions both historic and modern and the food is fantastic. So much to see, so much tapas to savour.

First trip to Seville and it certainly wont be the last. Plenty of attractions to visit and plenty to do which was free. Take ID if you are an EU citizen as you can visit many of the museums for free.
Beautiful city with interesting items but THE traffic is hell in those small streets you best take THE pop up and off busses who bring you to THE points of interest without parkingproblems

It is amazing how much history there is in this city. You see it when you are driving from the train station and see old Roman ruins right in center of town. Whether Alcazar or the Cathedral, the influences of the different cultures really makes Seville unique, and of course the history with Columbus is very fascinating. We had to choose either Barcelona or Seville for second leg of trip and really glad we chose Seville (nothing against Barcelona - that will be part of our next trip).
Vibrant, colourful and full of history. A magnet that you want to go back to over and over again. So much to see and enjoy, a blend or very modern and old. Sheer magic.

It is very simple, if one is in Spain for any time at all. Sevilla must be on the itinerary. Lots to see, good places to eat and just a really great vibe to the city. See the Plaza de Espana, climb to the top of the Catherdral, have a coffee in one of the outdoor cafe's. A place to take it easy and enjoy
Lots to do and see. Weather was fab . Suggest visiting the cathedral, alcarzar, espanol plaza, flamenco. We also went for a day trip to cordoba. This was,t long enough.

column2: “Loved Sevilla, a must on the list”
column3: We loved Sevilla. We were only there for a day and night, and wished we could have stayed longer. There was lots of great little boutiques for shopping, and the streets and plazas were so charming. Exactly what you want in a little European city! We want to go back and spend a little more time. We had also been to Madrid, Barcelona, and Grenada on this trip and enjoyed them all.

My second favourite city in the world so far. Big, lively, architecturally stunning and very Spanish. I wish I could spend days and days in the city. The food is also delicious. I want to go back already...
Full of Seville Orange Trees, very safe if you are alone. Plenty of bars and places to eat out, Very hot in Summer.

This is a vibrant city with a strong unique flavor. It is also in the middle of almost all Andalusia, so it is convenient for travelling to the other major destinations. The city proper has great restaurants, excellent flamenco, bullfighting (if you´re in to it), modern, barroque and ancient museums, palaces, churches...I mean you can enjoy food, arquitecture, painting, music and a people that are very, very friendly.This is a major destination in Spain so it is expensive--specially on holidays (the fair, Holly Week, among others). Here your dollar is worth a penny. This city is the most expensive in the peninsula.

column2: “A beautiful city filled with passion and orange trees”
column3: Compact within the old city where most of the main tourist sights are located...musicians and dancers of all kinds appear magically on the streets to entertain you. Sound of horse hooves on cobblestone streets is historical in feel and so beautiful as horses prance by pulling their fancy carriages behind them.The river divides the old from the newer and has a nice walk way along the blue ribbon where boats glide by.

column2: “Lovely welcoming city with lots to see and do”
column3: Seville gives the impression of not taking itself too seriously. Nice, easy going pace of life, warm weather and warm hospitality. Plenty of things to see and do from art to culture to history and good food. Visit sights such as the Cathedral and Alcazar or stroll along the river banks or through the old Santa Cruz district. Sip on a tinto de verano at a local bar whilst watching the world go by. What's not to like?!
lovly day in Sevilla with my family, i expect to come back in the future with my parents. its not difficult to get adn its not expensive

Seville is a wonderful city, where everyone can find smth special. it is a vibrant mix of old and modern architecture. If you like Flamenco, this is the city you should visit to see authentic Flamenco. it is safe and clean too. I just loved it and can't wait to return again.

column2: “One of the most beautiful cities in the world”
column3: Sevilla has it all: beautiful architecture, gardens and great food. What more could you ask for? Stay at least two or three days to absorb the beauty of the city, catch a few Flamenco shows and do some shopping.
Little to dislike.. Beautiful buildings and squares at every turn, travel from the Airport is really easy by bus at 4 Euros per person each way, and felt very safe.

We booked 3 nights in Seville and would have been happy if we'd done only 2 and added the third to Granada. We really enjoyed the Cathedral, Giralda tower, and Plaza de Espana especially. If we were to come again, we'd stay near Plaza Nueva or the Cathedral. The train station was great and made a visit to Cordoba easy and painless (but be sure to check on prices first because the ticket sellers will sell you more expensive tickets even if the train five minutes later costs half as much). February was cool but nice and the orange trees in the central part of the city were beautiful. Maria Luisa park is another must.

Sevilla jumps to the top of the list as one of my favorite European cities. Mellow, laid-back, with amazing architecture, museums, wine and food! Great for wandering and tapas-bar hopping. Highly recommend the Alameda de Hercules neighborhood. I will be going back someday to do come of the great day trips out of the city.

We LOVED Sevilla and can't wait to be back! One of our favourite European cities. If you have a choice plan to be there for at least one weekend during which Sevillans put on their best clothes and get out into the streets and gather in Tapas bars to socialize with friends and family!

column2: “An historic city with an eye on the future...”
column3: Not knowing what to expect of this city, but having it recommended by family, we were entranced by what it has to offer. We were lucky in that the hotel [whilst being not as good as we'd like in some respects] was central and within walking distance of more of the major sights. I wouldn't entertain driving through the narrow streets but, when we had to move farther afield, we discovered the taxis to be efficient, clean and not that expensive. There are some rundown areas (as in any city) but it felt safe at any time of the day especially as I walked a considerable distance both ways for a concert late at night. The Metropol Parasol is especially attractive at night and all the notable buildings are well-illuminated. Don't miss an opportunity to have a drive around some remarkable new pavilions built for the 1992 Universal Exposition of Seville (Expo '92) on La Isla de La Cartuja over the river. It would be impossible to walk the vast site. With children, the Isla Mágica (Magic Island) theme park on the former grounds of the Expo '92 might be worth visiting but it was closed when we were there. There is excellent shopping to be had in the city too. Downside? We didn't have enough time to see everything…

I liked Seville very much. Easy to get around, friendly locals and I noticed how clean it all was, very little graffiti anywhere and the old centre of Seville was immaculate. Everything was within walking distance of the hotel we stayed in. Never saw any problems just a few gypsies trying to sell heather but a polite "no" or a wave of the hand was enough to put them off. So many interesting buildings to see, photograph and visit and all on level ground, not a hill in sight. With cheap flights to Seville from the UK and other European destinations it's well worth a visit.

Now we have been we want to go back again! There is a lot to see in the way of buildings and gardens. Easy walking to most places and a good number of small bars for drinks and Tapas. The city reminded us of Havana Cuba but Seville is much cleaner and organised. I would highly recommend Seville for a city break and will definitely put this on the list for another visit. We were there in Feb and the weather was wetter than we would have liked. However, this meant the crowds were not there and we could appreciate the sights in peace!

Tight little streets in some places, and really difficult to drive in, loads of traffic. And so much to see and do, A lot of the Spaniards speak a little english, but if you at least greet them in their language and make an effort they will be more helpful. There is so much to do and see here. Magnificent city. Night time is buzzing, great food here, compared to Portugal.

There is so much to do, but we found 2 days was enough, then time to move on. The Alcazar (palace) was best, followed by the cathedral, but just walking around the old town was so enjoyable. Don't miss out Cordoba, about an hour's train ride away.

Seville is a city well worth a detour. Not the easiest place to drive around, and parking is difficult, but public transport is really good, and it's worth sampling the tapas bars rather than trying to find "proper" restaurants.

Our recent visit to Seville was a wonderful experience. During the day there are so many places of interest to visit and at night the city is so vibrant and, we found it, so safe.Plan your own itinery before you go so as not to waste time when you arrive. If you plan on visiting several attractions, consider purchasing a "Seville card". They can be purchased at the airport or train station or the tourist office . These were the only places we found which sold them.The best and most reasonably priced restaurants appear to be around the Cathedral. We enjoyed "Las Escobes" on Calle Alvarez Quintero in the evening and "Bodegan Torre Del Oro" on Calle Santander (near the Golden Tower) for lunch where their menu of the day (ask for it) comprised three well proportioned courses and a drink of your choice for 11.90 euros.

Seville is a truly marvellous city, visually stunning, small enough in the centre for visiting most attractions on foot and it has some of the best tapas in Spain, especially if you enjoy seafood. It's a great base too for trips to other cities in Andalucía and for the coast. In February the temperature was 17 degrees, Spring and Autumn have the nicest weather - avoid August, as it can be over 40 degrees in the shade! Once you have visited the city, you will want to go back again and again.

So many things to see, absolutely amazing, i found the locals very friendly and the beautiful flamenco dancers on the square absolutely amazing i was hypnotised for ages. I went to the cathedral and alcazar also the park that was amazing, there are so many fountains all around and so many places to go and things to do but would recommend a horse and carriage tour of the city
Put it on your list of places to see, it's a great city. easy to get around, lots of history, great places to eat and drink...we had 3 days there and could of stayed longer.

column2: “Nice place but not the best in spain..”
column3: I have visited many cities in spain and this time i decided to visit seville. I stayed 3 days in seville. the cathedral was beautiful but every cathedral is beautiful in spain. I could not see a huge difference. However the ambiance of the city was nice.. There is a big problem in seville. In spain you can have the best food even in small buffets.. But seville is very lack of good restaurants. We could not find a good place to eat.. All restaurants were seemed dirty to us.. Service was not very good and the tastes were not good enough for spain! So seville did not attract me a lot ..

The town has a lot of life--- for January. A lot of Cafes Restaurants and sites to visit. The weather was on our side so we did it all walking. Sightseeing is easy as everything is in proximity. The church is very special.
Sevilla is easily one of my favorite European cities. With plenty to do, see, eat and hear I am excited to mark this city high on my "return" list.

There is so much to see in a relatively compact old city centre. The restaurants of the old Jewish Quarter a great for tapas and atmosphere. Take the open top bus tour to get a feel for the wider city. Walking around with a map reveals beautiful buildings around every corner.

column2: “Seville is a gorgeous city for so many reasons.”
column3: There are some fantastic monuments to visit in Seville, especially for me the Real Alcazar stood out. The Cathedral is indeed monumental, and it is worth walking up the tower to see the views over the city. I also loved the gardens and green spaces around the city, and strolling by the river. There were old narrow streets full of twists and turns and character, and then there were wide boulevards bustling with people and grand buildings. Seville is a place to walk and chill out, and enjoy street cafes and bars, and fabulous cuisine. I am already looking forward to going again.

I have visited 110 countries in the world and all of the Spanish cities. Sevilla is my favourite for charm and beauty. I first visited the city in 1972 and I have been back so many times. Never disappointed. I will be back in July this year for a week.

Sevilla is such a beautiful city that one visit is not enough.I visited it with my friend for her birthday last January and I was amazed just how beautiful it is, especially the town centre. Oranges were growing everywhere, the architecture is amazing.I had to come back in December with my husband and he agrees with me, that it is not our last visit.The centre of Sevilla is very easy to walk. We had some Tapas in Triana also.I love the quirky streets of Sevilla and enjoy getting lost, having some Tapas and Sangia and trying to find my location again.I cannot wait for my next visit.

column2: “Sevilla is beautiful, romantic and teeming with life!”
column3: We loved our visit to Seville. It was so convenient to take a taxi from the Barajas Airport in Madrid to the Atocha Train Station and to take a high-speed train down to Seville in 2 hours. Seville's Old Town is beautiful, mostly a walking only area and over the Christmas holidays was teeming with life -- both Spaniards and tourists enjoying the mild -- though not balmy weather, the wonderful restaurants, the flamenco, the historical attractions and the boisterous activity in the streets.It is a really bad idea to take a taxi to anything in the old town since it is so difficult for the taxis to find streets open to vehicles and since the ones that exist are often only one car wide. Walking is the best and sometimes only way to get where you are going, but the shops and restaurants make the walks extremely pleasant. The streets are lined with neatly trimmed orange trees which were laden with fruit over Christmas and which contributed to the holiday atmosphere.I especially loved the beautiful Spanish horses that stood by with carriages for the tourists to ride on. They were beautiful and well trained horses such as I have rarely seen anywhere.We loved the Alcazar, the Cathedral and the Geralda and hope to come back and catch more sights and more tapas again the future. We loved spending the Christmas season in Seville.By the way, be sure to book hotels early for holidays in Seville. It is only a 2 hour train ride from Madrid and the Madrilenos love go there for hoidays.
if to portugal go on a daytrip to sevilla real nice place to go lot to c and lots to do u wont be dissapointed and for 19 euros a real bargain

This is my second trip and things have changed since my last. The Pedestrianization of the central areas due to the Tram infrastructure have made Seville EVEN better. The area around the Cathedral and Alcazar is transformed by the paved areas.Seville is SO CLEAN, the cleanest city I have ever been to, the pavements almost sparkle!Top things to do areCatherdral and Giralda, The Alcazar, Plaza Espana and the other 1929 expo buildings (exteriors), Santa Cruz (Jewish quarter) The Metropolitan Parasols.We did a boat tour which from The Golden Tower and to be honest it wasn't that great as most of the sights are masked by trees!Seville is just so pretty that I can't wait to go back....Oh and its lovely in January, warm enough and very quiet so you get to see everything without Huge crowds!!

on the banks of the Guadalquiver, Seville is the Paris of Spain. A simply stunning city, vibrant with elegant architecture, especially the Plaza de Espanya. We visited in the late afternoon. The buildings shimmered gold, the water a magical quicksilver and the reflections an Impressionist painting. Brilliant ceramic tile work, horse drawn carriage rides. Very romantic. Moorish horseshoe arches, flower beds, water channels, porches and patios. Alleyways and hidden doorways where Bizet placed his opera Carmen. A truly magic city. Easy to walk around andloads to see. A visual feast.
As Michener said "Sevilla doesn't have ambience, it is ambience". One of the most beautiful cities in the world. Go and spend some time and you'll love it.

An outstanding city very well worth a long weekend away to. From the Alcazabar, to the parks, the truly outstanding cathedral and Giraldar, this city has it all. Oh did I mention the food and tapas and sherry?

We loved Sevilla. We loved the atmosphere of the narrow streets, especially around the Alcazar, and the fact that it is very easy to get around, either walking or using public transport. It was also very good city to use as a jumping off point for other cities such as Cordoba.

This is one of the most atmospheric places in Spain. The streets around the cathedral and university are full of fabulous bars, restaurants and tapas. The city has amazing parks, monuments, churches and museums. Packed with history as once the capital, it is clean tidy and the people are welcoming. This city is not to be missed on tour trip to Southern Spain.

column2: “A must visit when in Southern Spain”
column3: You need a good guide book, too many places of interest to list but of course Alcazar palace is one place you must visit. There are fantastic hidden alleys with brilliant restaurants, bars of every description. You need a couple of days at least to see this wonderful city, just avoid July/August too hot.

In Sevilla I fell in love with spanish food and culture! People are so nice, the traditional spanish food is amazing. I got chance to see also some carnivals and that was one big plus to my experience!

Seville is a must if you go to Southern Spain. Not as crowded as Madrid. Very walkable. Loved the horse carriages that waited by the main Cathedral. We had a wonderful centrally located hotel (Casa 1800) so we could walk everywhere. Arrived and departed by train so don't know where one would park a car. Went to see Flamenco and I was happy for the experience. Best tapas. Wine is good and very inexpensive of course it is everywhere in Spain. Want to return to Seville.

Sad we only had two days there, but we really enjoyed it, and would like to go back to the city and hopefully see more of the area around as well. Attractions well worth spending time on: The Cathedral, Giralda tower, Alcazar, Plaza de Espana, a promenade along the river.

As my friend said, the people of Seville can be justly proud of their city. There are so many things to see and do, historically as well as culturally, and all so clean. The people were universally pleasant and helpful, so we had a marvellous time. Highly recommended.
Seville is one of the best destinations in Spain. If you love culture, this is the way to go. Great food, music, shopping, and history. Don't miss it!
In a good way, this city has a lot of culture in a small package and plenty of restaurants to enjoy your stay. Worth visiting.

It's beautiful because it's a typical spanish town and because it's not as big as Madrid or Barcellona... It's compact and still has lots to do... you can just walk in the city center and still have tons to see and do.. the palaces, gardens, orange trees, bull ring, flamenco dances and food are just amazing... a must visit !!

We traveled throughout spain and Sevilla is a magical and compact city. It has a special character to it, which probably comes the palaces, cathedrals and the flamenco.Nice walk along the Guadalquivir river which ends at the charles bridge and the bull ring museum is close to the charles bridge.All the main tourist locations are around the central square and do not muss the Barrio Santa Cruz walk
only a few hours from Malaga airport a must see destination for Andalucía Spain.....................the old barrio and the new city are great to spend money for beautiful treasures
travelled alone for a week, best week ever! what a warm, wonderful and delicious city! great food, history, people, bodegas, city, sights... MUST SEE!

We went to lots of places but the Bull Ring tour was great.Our guide was very knowledgeable and didn't mind anserwring questions in English.The history is fascenating even if you dont like bullfighting the tour is awesome,thr ring [wow]The city itself is amazing with so much to see,try it.At Christmas ther is a monthlong light show which takes place every evening[3 times] and the buzzzz of people moving around is mindblowing,everywhere is packed so the restaurants are full,the bars just rock,no matter what your age this is a great place to visit.
Sevilla is nice and compact, not crowded with tourists in December and feels like a place where normal Spaianards live.

Just an enchanting city filled with singing drunks. And I mean that in a very good way. :) People lined their favorite cafe's drinking, signing, and dancing impromptu Flaminco. Although this isn't reason enough to do this city any justice, I figured that this is something different then the normal "Oh how absolutely gorgeous the city is" review :)
Spent 5 days here and could have stayed for longer. A beautiful place, an upmarket part of Spain. Great place to wander around and sites all around.

Strongly recommend Sevilla for a 3 day visit. It is a wonderful city with much to see and do, great restaurants and vibrant residents. Highlights include Plaza de Espana, Alcazar and the Cathedral. But just walking around the city is a great experience.

Too much to see and do, a trip to Spain must include this beautiful and well kept town.Make sure you watch a traditional flamenco show and visit both Arabic and Spanish historical monuments. No need for a car. Allow 2.full days at least.

column2: “Sevilla - great food, great city, GREAT PEOPLE!”
column3: We visited in Dec, and "lucked out" - it rained the day we arrived and when we left - bright crisp wintry days in between in the 50's F (low teens C). Couldn't ask for better weather!The city is an easy "walking" city, taking the narrow streets, sometimes without sidewalks into account - it is a walking city, so come prepared with good walking shoes and be prepared to walk for miles exploring the city. Of course, there could be breaks in between visiting the various sites, just sitting in lovely parks and of course, stopping by the Tapas Bars for a quick bite.... oh to be a tourist in Seville!There are lots more people seemingly at night in the city center than in the day time - guess night = locals + tourists. Quite a party town especially on weekends! There is a laser light show near the Plaza Neuva, that is cool, and of course lots of Tapas Bars - did I say tapas again?The people we met were friendly and very helpful - they went above and beyond to help us despite language barriers (thank you Google Translate!) To me, this is a city to go off the beaten path, to explore and interact with the locals -there is so much to discover and appreciate!If you have a smart phone that is unlocked (try to borrow one if you dont), get a local sim card and get unto the Google Maps for navigation - we found that to be so much more useful and helpful than trying to read maps - might even save your relationship if you are here with your significant other! (Try navigating with a map of a maze...)Other than that, there is not much more great things to be said about Seville that has not been said - it is that and much more to be experienced and enjoyed.Enjoy and oh yes, watch out for the Gypsy Lady that comes offering thyme...

column2: “An amazing city - make sure you visit the river!”
column3: Our first day in Seville was sunny and warm - which was a welcome relief from the cool days in Madrid. We wandered down to the river and found a little floating bar where we sat in the sun and enjoyed a few beverages. Highly recommend the Cathedral and the Alcazar.
Most people dealing with tourists speak some English. However our companions both were fluent in Spanish. The transportation is good. Finding a good place for breakfast was difficult.

Seville was one of those cities that has a lot for the tourist looking to idle away a couple of days, whilst still remaining a city for the Spanish locals. As a tourist visits to the Cathedral and Alcazar and trips up the Giralda and Metrapol Parasol are a must and there are lots of alleys and backstreets to get lost in, but the city still bustles with locals shopping in the smart, pedestrianized centre and eating and drinking in the enormous number of bars and restaurants. Was there during December, so not sure what it is like in peak season, but for Europeans should certainly be added to the 'long weekend' list along with the more usual destinations

We stayed in the old part of Seville near Plaza del Salvador. please take the time to see the inside of this church. We went one night when they had a procession into the neighborhood.We enjoyed the hardware store on the corner and found we needed things that we didn't know existed.We could walk from the square to everything that interested us.Alcazar, Cathedral y Giralda, Flamenco, river which includes museums and bull ring, and of course shops and restaurants.We took the bus tour and found that only the old part of the city held our interest.

Seville is a beautiful city, so easy to get around and breathtaking monuments and parks. The walk by the river is nice. The old town is worth a visit and the tapas are good. The drinks and food are reasonably priced.

Lot of orange treess is interesting.Taking a bus tour for 17 Euros is waste.Walking tour is better.Walkable from city center.Oranges at the street are not meant for pliucking and consuming they are used for making marmalades.
A gem,you must go there,but not in summer is to hot.great place ,lots of gardens,plants ,orange trees everywhere,when in flower ,the perfume is everywhere ;))

The motorway from Malaga brings you into the heart of the city. Then, just find a carpark (there are lots of underground ones) and leave the car. The heart of the city, centred on the cathedral, isn't very big, but you'll find it hard to drive round. Once you're in, just relax and enjoy the sights and the food. Some fantastic tapas bars and bodegas which I would recommend above restaurants. Lovely feel to this city - so much to do, so much to see, and so much to eat!!
Loved Sevilla though not as much as Granada and Cordoba. Defiantly worth spending a few days in though the other two we're more me, enjoy.

As the last, but by no means least, in the row of visited cities in Spain, was the Sevilla, the real jewel among the other gemstones in the beautiful region Andalusia.Sevilla is the capital and biggest city of the autonomous community of Andalusia, and as well, the center of the province of Sevilla. The grand river, the Rio Guadalquivir flows also through the body of this city, as it does upstream through the Cordoba. The splendid, old bridges are spanned across the Rio Guadalquivir, like the Bridge Isabell II, better known as the Triana Bridge, then Puente de Saint Telmo, Puente de Los Remedios, Puente Cristo de la Expiracion, to mention only these ones, in the old part of city or in the strict center of the same.Here are the worth of the visit, three UNESCO World Heritage Sites, that are : the Alcazar palace complex, the Sevilla Cathedral with Giralda Tower and the General Archive of the Indies.The city was founded by Romans and after them in the beginning of eighth century, was the Muslim conquest, when the city fell under the power of Caliphate of Cordoba. In about the middle of XIII century, came the Castillian era.Walking in the nice and old and modern streets, You can observe a lot of interesting buildings, meet the beautiful people, enjoy in great ambiance and great meals of Spanish kitchen in the numerous restaurants. You can taste also the excellent wines, the tapas, listen to flamenco in the bars and restaurants, taverns.I remember, that I liked then, a lot, the Plaza de Espana,the Isabell the Second bridge, the Seville Cathedral with adjoined Bell Tower,Giralda Tower, from which heights, You can see the courtyard of Cathedral and roof of the Cathedral.The very originally made is the facade of the Palace of San Telmo, that is the seat of the presidency of the Andalusian Autonomous Government.To return to the Plaza de Espana, since I prefer always the vast Plazas with surrounding it,the remarkable buildings, that one grabbed my sight with its Regionalist Revival Architecture and mixture of diverse historic styles, among the other, the Art Deco, which buildings are covered with glazed tiles.Here are also the number of very good museums, such a Museum of Fine Arts, of Bullfight, the Flamenco Art Museum and many more.The Alcazar Gardens give You impression, that You are, somewhere, in some beautiful oasis in the northern Africa and not in Europe.In the Cathedral of Seville, I recall that I stood for a while, in front of the tomb of Christopher Columbus, due to his enormous importance in the planetary scope.Just catchy memories about this wonderful city, on the banks of Rio Guadalquivir, indeed!
The best the walks in the downtown. The Giralda, Cathedral, Santa Cruz neighborhood, the tapas and Cruzcampo beer, .... Very dificult to park in the downtown.
i did not get an AAAHHHHH experience in Madrid - but in Seville, it touched my heart.The streets are enoyable and the restaurants worth to be hungry.

This city is charming and romantic with a great riverfront where the locals hangout or go on their daily run/jog. Sevilla is fairly small in area, but it's still easy to get lost on little street/alleys so beware at night because it's difficult to read street signs in the dark!Take advantage of the free walking tours (pay a tip of about 5 euros ) with Poncho Tours--they are great! There are 3 tour routes in town.Make sure you carve out at least 3 hours to go visit the Alcazar (royal palace) and an hour to visit Sevilla's cathedral (make sure the Giralda tower is open the day you go, so you can enjoy the great views from the top!)Sevilla is a place where Spanish tourists as well as foreign tourists enjoy the laid back atmosphere of Andalusia!

Come here if you want to visit a city with beautiful people, sights, ambience, old world corners, great tapas, good wine, great sights, good parks and music everywhere. If you enjoy strolling corners and smelling good food. If you want reasonable prices in Europe. If you like these things, come along. There's also good shopping and a raging nightlife. People from everywhere are here! I've been here three weeks and have two more months to go. I can't imagine wanting to leave this new found paradise!!

column2: “A fabulous city to return to again and again”
column3: An entirely beautiful old city in which you can walk endlessly and still find new corners. I love the colours the houses are painted with their characteristic dark yellow round windows and doors. Yellow and terracotta abound. Narrow streets. Stunning old palaces, wonderful wrought iron gates into tiled patios, gorgeous doors. Wonderful old shop fittings which should be seen before they disappear. Seville by night is even more picturesque when all the bars and shops are lit up and you can see in. A great buzz and a great place for the young who are on the streets outside the bars chatting and having fun. Great authentic tapas bars and plenty to do in the evenings. Night clubs, a concert at the Maestranza theatre, flamenco bars, and really good restaurants. An easy place to visit if you stay centrally near the Cathedral. There are lovely walks along the river and attractions and shops all around. There is so much to see. You need a minimum of 3-4 days in the winter season. The summer is impossibly hot.

Sevilla, one of the most important Andaluzan cities (along with Granada and Cordoba) is a must, especially for Latin Americans as history was made there with the conquest and the commerce during the colonial era. The carriage is a great way to see the sites where you can go back at your leisure.

Brilliant! Lovely to explore and wander around the little streets and alleyways. Naturally the Alcazar and Cathedral are worth visiting, and we enjoyed the park Maria Louisa with its magnificent Plaza d'Espagna.

Seville has many things to offer the tourist, and this includes museums, sights, and churches. Even if you stay a whole week, you will not be able to see everything. I love the churches in the city because they have so much art that I enjoy seeing. The shopping streets like Calle Sierpes are very good and full of shoe stores. There are many good restaurants in the city too. The people are very friendly also. Most sights are walkable.

Spend at least 3 days here to fully enjoy all the sites. Don't try to add a day trip to Cordoba into the schedule. Cordoba deserves another day on its own. There are so many great areas of the city to explore. Plaza Espana is beautiful..try to visit it early in the morning when there are less tourists. We loved all the neighbourhood walks, Cathedral, tower, Alcazar, stroll along the Guadalqivir on a Saturday a.m. watching the kayakers, a visit of the bull ring....and if we had time, we would have also booked a bike tour at the start of the visit. Great city to bike in..lots of paths through the city and parks. Enjoy and don't forget to see a flamenco show one evening.

This city is truly breathtakingly beautiful. It must be Spain's best keep secret. Incredibly friendly people, amazing food, and fantastic memories of happy times amongst outstanding architecture. Go there... take a walking tour, go to the Plaza de Espana, eat tapas in the street and soak up the atmosphere. You'll wonder why you've never been before!

We took a day trip from Marbella to Seville - a long day but well worth it. We first visited the Plaza de Espana which was built for the 1929 exhibition - really big and impressive. Each province of Spain is represented there. The canal is crossed over by bridges decorated with beautiful ceramics. We then took a small walk through the Maria Luisa Park to the Santa Cruz quarter (previously known as the Jewish quarter). There are lots of narrow streets with beautiful buildings. Our last visit was to the Cathedral which is huge (!). It was built on the site of the old Mosque. All that remains of the old Mosque is the Giralda tower - a mineret built by the Moors to which the Christians added a bell tower. Inside the Cathedral you are overwelmed by its size. The retable of the high altar is huge. You can also see the tomb of Christopher Columbus as well as that of his son and much more. Seville is a memorable place to visit if you love historical places.
Seville is worth a least 4 days, don't go in Summer though, it can get very hot.Choose a hotel or even better an apartment in the old district Barrio Santa Cruz

Although not a capital city Seville has some of the finest monumental buildings in Europe, testimony to the extraordinary wealth brought back to Spain by the Conquistadors. Well worth exploring the narrow streets of the Barrio Santa Cruz on foot and stopping off at the numerous cafes, bars and restaurants to sample the tapas. Or rest your legs by taking a horse and carriage around the streets. Traffic is not a problem in the centre, which is pedestrian-friendly.

column2: “Sevilla, capital of Andalucia - I love this city”
column3: It was my first visit to Spain and the fact the it was Sevilla it made it an amazing experience. The town is beautiful, the people are so warm and friendly and the tapas are so good. You have to visit La Triana ( the home of the Flamenco), Giralda, Alcazar, La Plaza de Toros, Plaza de Espana and El Parasol. But you if just want to chill you can easily get lost on the beautiful narrow streets of the city and feel the energy of the people. The food is very tasty, you have to try the different types of tapas in Los Coloniales and Dos d Mayo; but what i really liked was the service, the way they treat you as one of their own.La Triana is the place of Flamenco, so you have to see a show and live the emotions through this wonderful dance, these people are so pasionate about their traditions, you will see them dancing and singing in the streets.

Not the magic of Barcelona or Venice, but a delightful place to wander around in the autumn sunshine. The narrow streets of the old city make driving an experience and parking a nightmare. The mix of architecture, cafe culture and lack of traffic in the old town is a great mix. There are areas around the cathedral where tourist prices apply, but in general costs are reasonable. A beer around the Almeda can be as little as 1 euro. The winding narrow streets of the Jewish quarter are a rabbit warren but well worth the visit as is the Alcazar. A good guide book really pays dividends, we found the walking tours in Frommer's Seville day by day highly entertaining.

An ancient city with lots of historic buildings. Amazingly interesting architecture everywhere, mostly in the Moorish style, and beautiful gardens full of exotic trees & plants. Lovely food and friendly people, all well worth a visit!

I lived here for four months for study abroad, and it's a gorgeous wonderful city! If you have never been to Spain before you might experience some culture shock ("spain time", lack of English in non-touristy areas, times of meals, times of business hours, siesta, and just the way people generally carry themselves). I cannot imagine having lived anywhere else, Sevilla is very true to its historical and cultural roots, and you see this during times of celebration and in the architecture and history which is still present in the town (torre del oro). Enjoy Sevilla!!!

I lived in Sevilla for a few months while in college, and went back this past spring. Sevilla is by far my favorite city in Spain (I have been to all the majors and alot of smaller cities as well). It is rich in history, social attractions, great food, wine and sunshine. The people are friendly, but english is not widely spoken as you might find in Madrid or Barcelona. Must see attractions: Plaza de Espana, Triana, La Catedral y La Giralda, Alcazar, & various museums. Kayak along the river if you can! You will see some I think that the ideal amount of time for a short visit would be 4-5 days (obviously more if you're able).

What a beautiful city!So many things to see from so many cultures. The history is so rich. Beautiful buildings and beautiful parks. Very friendly and helpfull people and lots of nice tapas bars, and very cheap.

Seville is a beautiful place with several historical and cultural venues. The faith of the Sevillians is manifested in the innumerable and heavily decorated churches and convents strewn across the city, together with the extreme devotion shown towards Our Lady of Sorrows and the Redeemer. Their works of art expressed in ceramics are a joy to see, especially when one visits the magnificent Plaza Espana where even the balustrades are made of ceramic. Each winding street in the historic (even off the beaten path) centre produces some surprise or place of interest. The best product Seville has is undoubtedly the Sevillians themselves. They are simply warm and wonderful and go out of their way to make you feel welcome even though their command of English is almost nil; however, they still somehow manage to communicate.

It's fairly safe to say that I am very well travelled. I have spent many a time travelling with my husband as his job took him abroad six months out of every year, so I feel that I am qualified to comment on Sevilla as one of the most appealing cities that I have visited to date.With its narrow cobbled streets and winding roads, Sevilla is a city of quaintness and charm. Every street has an abundance of coffee shops, tapas bars, charming little leather and trinket stores and some of the streets even remind me of being in an Arab bazaar.I find the ambience and charm of this city thoroughly irresistible and I was constantly surprised at how much there is to see and do.I loved the Arabesque architecture because the Arabs ruled Spain for 700 years and therefore the influence of the Middle East is very apparent at every street and building. This type of history all adds to the flavour and atmosphere of the city.Sevilla has it all, modern designer shopping, sophisticated restaurants, a glorious riverside experience and some of the most beautiful and opulent churches I have seen. It is seeped in history and is a busy, thriving, bustling little gem.If culture is your thing, then there are an abundance of art galleries and museums.I haven't reviewed the tourist attractions here, but they are well publicised and within easy reach of the city and surrounding areas.I have found the people in mainland Spain to be kind, courteous, helpful and respectful. I cannot praise them highly enough and the people of Sevilla are no exception.I would suggest learning a smattering of street Spanish before your trip, as English is not spoken widely here and not all menus are translated into English.The summer months are scorching but the temperature cools towards the end of September and beginning of October, so if you are like myself and don't like the searing heat of a Mediterranean sun, then autumn is a beautiful time of the year to get around and sightsee in comfort.All in all, a wonderful and memorable experience and one which I hope to repeat in the future.

We visited for three days.Our accommodation was close to the Alcazar and Cathedral in a narrow and very quiet street,an ideal place to unwind and enjoy the hospitality of Sevilla!We found everyone to be very friendly and so helpful, and Sevilla is such a beautiful city with so much to see and do.

My favourite place in the entire world! I've lived there and I can't wait to go back, but this time, to buy a house and move in with my husband.The city is beautiful, people are really kind, the weather is perfect and the best thing is that most people don't have cars and they go everywhere by foot or riding a bike.The city is not very big but it has everything you need: good restaurants, bars, clubs, parks, shops and so on.What I like the most about Sevilla is the way people like there, that is so different from life in big cities. People are always smiling and enjoying life. I love it.

Look this city one of my favorites. It has the history with bull fight, old buildings, church and Alcatar with some influence from the northern Africans over time. Not a big city that has become too industrialized. Culture with flamenco and paella.

column2: “BEWARE OF VIATOR DAY TOURS of SEVILLE”
column3: In Apriil we took the VIATOR day tour from Malaga to Seville The highlights of the tour, as listed on their website, are as follows.HighlightsFull-day tour to Seville from MalagaVisit the UNESCO World Heritage-listed Cathedral of St Mary and the AlcazarEnjoy a panoramic sightseeing tour of SevilleSee the lively Triana, La Macarena and Santa Cruz quartersDiscover the beautiful Giralda Tower and the Maria Luisa ParkHave free time to explore Seville at your own paceLine two of the highlights turned out to be a problem. The clear implication from this single sentence is that you will visit BOTH the Cathedral and the Alcazar. They are of course, the main things one MUST see in Seville. As it turns out, the tour takes you through the cathedral but only walks you past the Alcazar – kind of large discrepancy there in what constitutes a “visit”, especially when both are included in the same sentence. We were fortunate that our local guide (not the onboard bus guide) provided us with a resolution. Once we finished the guided tour of the Cathedral, we broke away from the tour, missing the tours of the quarters and went through the Alcazar on our own. We then met the group back at the Giralda tower to board the bus back to Malaga. So we saw the Alcazar but had to give up parts of the planned tour to do what we had signed up to get.When we got home and received the email request from Viator to write a review we did. It basically included the negative comments made above and a zero or one star rating. To our utter amazement, when the review actually appeared on the Viator website, this is what was published as being our review.“We were fortunate to have an engaging guide. Given the time constraints, the tour was very good and provided everything as advertised.” And the rating was listed as either 4 or 5 stars.We were amazed at the audacity of Viator and hope to warn others of the unreliability of this companies practices, especially regarding reviews on its website solicited from its customers.

The trip advisor web servers wouldn't let me add this as a comment on the parking page, but I thought my recent experience of parking in Seville in April 2013 might help someone.We stayed in Barrio Santa Cruz for 5 days but we had to have a car to return to Malaga and to wander round Andalusia for the first part of our 10 day holiday. There were loads of questions about parking in Seville, and not very many helpful answers. Most said to park in the Cano y Cueto underground car park. I would say don't, unless you have a very small car. The car park was designed for the old Seat 500 I would imagine, as for our Citroen C4 it was a very tight squeeze, not helped by the selfish or incompetent parking of others. Other guides say you can pay with a credit card. Not true. You can't. The machine only takes 5 and 10 euro notes. It costs 24 euro (April 2013) to park for 24 hours. There aren't 350 places as the other guides state, as only about 100 are for temporary visitors. Are you paying for security? Not really, as the staff are often absent doing their own thing - anyone could come in and steal stuff from your car. Unlikely i know, but still possible and it does happen.We moved our car after 24 hours to on street car parking on the Calle Inca Garcilaso, just over the bridge from the main bus station. It's in between the RED building and the tall uncompleted tower you can see from everywhere in Seville. It's a busy road 24 hours a day and the car was still there unharmed after 4 days. I did visit once to check it was ok and I noticed that the cars in front and behind had also chosen to stay for a few days.There is free parking to the north and west of this spot, in the car parks that were built for the Expo 92 (not much of a lasting legacy there, as many buildings are derelict). OK for the day, but the more you see homeless people round camp fires, the more dodgy it seems for an overnight stay. There is a 24 hour secure car park for commercial vehicles nearby, but I did see several cars in it. For a lorry it's 10 euros per night, but I expect you could negotiate a lower price for a car. You go up Calle Inca Garcilaso, turn left on Calle Juan Antonio de Vizarron, go under the tunnel and turn left. The car park is a bit of an opportunist thing, very familiar to me in my home town of Manchester, where building and derelict sites are always commandeered by "enterprising" individuals who charge less than official prices to "mind your car" . It looks like a scrap yard and there is a gate with a man in a little shed. These are the co-ordinates37.392417,-6.013816.All this area will be re-developed of course when the Eurozone revives. But I think it will be available for a few years yet as all the European vanity projects have dried up for the time being. For a day trip to Seville I would park in any of the Expo car parking areas on the Isla de la Cartuja, walk over the nearest bridge, and catch a bus or taxi into the Barrio Santa Cruz.

column2: “Places we enjoyed eating at in Seville”
column3: We stayed at the Hotel King Alfonso XIII in Seville and never needed to take a taxi as it was so centrally located. We did a lot of walking which is the best way to discover some unique places to eat. We had two meals at Vineria San Telmo on Paseo de Catalina de Ribera 4 which was highly recommended on Tripadvisor and it didn't disappoint. Delicious salads (you can google their menu) - mixed greens with pear and blue cheese and fresh spinach with cheese, apples, mushrooms and mustard vinaigrette. I wanted to try the Spanish potato omelette which we saw all over Spain but sadly didn't. We had the deep fried chunks of breaded chicken breast with potatoes (very good) and tried the squid ink spaghetti with scallops (tasty but not for everyone!). You can be adventurous here - probably everything on the menu is pretty good. For some of their dishes, they have varying sizes, i.e. tapas serving, small and big dishes. In the area of Barrio Santa Cruz, we stumbled upon Mama Goye ice cream (went back twice in the same day!) - heavenly - with wonderful flavors - small shop mostly take out - cups/cones. My favorite flavor - sweet cream with chunks of chocolate. In the same general area we enjoyed the most wonderful soups at Extraverde at Plaza Dona Elvira 8 (you can google it), very sophisticated gem of a find. They are noted for their cheeses, wines, tapas and various olive oils which you can taste. I had their cold almond soup (not sweet) - it was amazing. My husband had their cold tomato soup which was similar to gazpacho, also delicious. I tasted orange wine for the first time - a liquer made in Seville - lovely. We had a pizza one night at an outdoor cafe on San Fernando, the street in front of the hotel. As you exit the hotel, cross the street and go right. You will see outdoor cafe after cafe but the one with the really thin crust pizza is the place (before you get to the end of the street) - sorry I cannot be more specific (it's near the cafe that advertises flamenco). Enjoy!!!!!!!!!!

Seville is a beautiful place, but a word to those who are going to the airport from Santa Cruz by taxi as we traveled this morning. The traveling time was 12 minutes and the cost was 29.50 euro. We will going to Seville again next year no doubt but will be using the bus next time as this costs 2.40 euro one way and takes around 25 minutes.

column2: “Sevilla Historic City Center review and driving tip”
column3: Sevilla Historic City Center is amazingly beautiful. The cathedral is the 3rd largest church in Europe only after St. Paul’s in London and St. Peter’s at the Vatican. The Corona de la Virgen de los Reyes in the treasury is a must see as it contains the world’s largest pearl, and the Giralda Bell Tower provides wonderful view of Sevilla. The Alcazar is also gorgeous. Other favorites of ours while there were the flamenco show at Auditorio Alvarez Quintero near the cathedral and the delicious and beautifully presented tapas at Almiranta Tapas-Restaurante also near the cathedral (c/Almirantazgo 2). And yes, we would recommend staying in the historic city center to really get the feel of Sevilla.So, now you’ve booked yourself a great place to stay during your Sevilla visit, smack center of everything, and you just can’t wait to check-in and get yourself settled in. If you have a rental car with you, save yourself some time and stress and hire a taxi! If you really want to drive into the historical center, you should hire a taxi to lead you to the address. For about 5E, it will save you a lot of headaches and time. Even with a GPS, it was impossible because not all little alleys are marked and some alleys are so narrowed or have tables and chairs set up by restaurants around there that you cannot get by. So, you would have to keep taking a different alley than what your GPS tells you. Consequently, your GPS would have to “recalculate” and you and it would become deeper into the abyss! We rented a great apartment just a stone throw from the cathedral (just off of Avenida de la Constitucion) and were offered a safe parking in a parking building near the apartment for 14E per day with in/out privilege, which we jumped at (we were going to take the rental car out for a day trip or two during our stay). What a mistake that was to think that we could drive to our rental apartment and parking in the historic city center. We gave it 3 tries (after each time, we managed to pop out onto a larger street so we and our GPS could figure out where we were before attempting again), and we still could not get ourselves to our apartment (to our defense, we drove to many other cities during our 3-week trip but didn’t have as much trouble as in Sevilla and we shared the same driving nightmare as other tourists in Sevilla that we chatted with). So, after an hour, we hired a taxi so we could follow him to our apartment. It even took him a little while to figure the alleys that we could drive on to get us to our apartment. Then you’d think the nightmare was over, but no, not yet! The parking building is very safe with automatic gate and attendant. Perfect. However, to get our car parked, we had to drive into a tiny car elevator that barely fits our brand new rental Renault Megane Tourer (we were its first driver) and then back out in a very narrow area and then get the car into our narrow assigned parking spot, which happens to be right next to the elevator! Needless to say, once we took our car out to a day trip, we never did park there again. Upon our return from our day trip, we parked at the underground public parking garage on Paseo de Cristobal Colon near the bulling, which was about 12-16E overnight parking, to avoid having to drive in the historical center and to re-park at the spot we had already paid for! If we were to re-do, we would just park at this underground public parking garage in the first place. It was only just 5-minute walk from our rental apartment and walking with our suitcases out to it the morning that we checked out of our apartment was really not bad at all. Believe it or not, even with the driving nightmare, our Sevilla visit was still wonderful.

This was my first visit to Seville, having been recommended by a work colleague who is Spanish. As a keen amateur photographer, I was really looking forward to this trip (21st to 25th June) with all of the many sites to visit during my trip.It is a very easy city to navigate once you have worked out the layout of the tiny streets, some too narrow for traffic, and some where you need to step into a doorway to avoid cars (mainly taxis).I stayed at the Vime Corredigor, a small hotel in the La Macarena area of the city, which is about 15 minutes walk to the main city centre. My stay was on a room only basis - there are plenty places to eat in the city - you will certainly not go hungry.One word of warning - if you intend to catch the train to spend the day in Cordoba like me, you really should get a taxi to the station (Santa Justa) as it is very easy to get lost trying to walk there, as I nearly found to my cost.Seville's best sites are best seen by walking everywhere - you get to appreciate the architecture that much more. The highlight's for me were the Catedral (the view from the top of the La Giralda tower is amazing) and the Plaza de Espana.Also try to cross the river to walk around the Triana area - this is where all of the ceramic tiles are produced for the city, and is a quaint area to visit.I have returned with so many good memories and hopefully some nice photo's. I certainly can't wait to go back sometime soon.

Arrived into Seville by bus form Portugal. Walked into the centre of the city from the new bus station. The tourist information at the bus station depends on your luck of who is working, onn the way in we met a lovely lady who was very helpful BUT on the way out we met a bloke who was just putting in his time (couldnt care less).Seville is a very exciting city and really come alive in the evening (we were there in May when the day time temperatures are just starting to climb and he nights are beautiful).If you do nothing else in seville you must visit the Alcazar and the Cathedral. We found that the queues were very long first thing in the morning but by the afternoon you could walk straight in.The dining was great, al fresco at night is the way to go. I also suggest that late at night get yourself a drink (maybe a jug of Sangria) and do some people watching.There are many Flamenco Shows but be very choosy about where you go. Avoid the dinner and show style pushed hard by the hotels, its all a bit ho-hum. BUT if that is the only chance you get to see Flamenco take it.

We have just returned from a 4 day trip in Seville. This was our first time in Spain. We stayed at the Hercules Apartment just overlooking Alameda de Hércules and we couldn’t have chosen a better place to be. The area is lovely so are the surrounding restaurants. The open space at Alameda de Hércules is ideal for everyone, with 3 spots of playground equipment for children and 3 water sprinklers areas ... very convenient in warm temperature. We saw children and adults playing together with dogs in these particular 'refreshing' areas .... Oh even cyclists washing their bicycles!We went through all the main historical sites which were only a couple of minutes walking away from our apartment. Public transport is very reliable and not expensive at all.I would say it was one of my perfect holidays - strolling, eating tapas and drinking beers, sangria and mohitos ... what else does one need :) The weather was perfect, sunny and warm with temperatures at 33 degrees.The only thing that marred my visit was attending the bull fight. I am not against any cultural traditions infact my motto is "when in Rome do as the Romans do" and therefore we paid €70 to attend a bullfight with tickets in the shade and in fourth row so I have to admit I was eager for the event. However I never realised I was so sensitive to seeing any creature die in front me. Hence after the first 'fight' we opted to leave. I have to admit it effected me emotionally but I still respect Spain’s traditions. So I will not enter into any polemics whatsoever.Therefore back to Seville ..... Chris de Burgh with his Spanish Train kept coming to my mind every time we crossed the Guadalquivir River.The Moorish buildings are impressive and a lovely contrast to the modern buildings. Everything and everyone blends together in Seville.Well yes I have to admit I didn’t think I was going to enjoy Seville so much and for sure this will not be my one and only visit there though I'd love to visit other Spanish cities first.

If you like relax traveling, Seville is the right city for this concept. Around ever corner there is an event going on, people dancing, singing, with the help of sangria of course. The food is great, weather was great in May (probably the best time to visit) and for sure flamenco. Only problem is to catch the shops to buy some stuff since they have siesta forever.

We went to Seville at the last minute in our route from Marbella to Portugal. Beautiful architecture. Seville is classic Spain. Be careful during the summer, it's so hot and humid and I'm from the southern US and was still dying! The Gothic Quarters are very confusing and you'll probably get lost but there's always something to discover around every corner. I was in a study abroad program in Spain when I was in college so I've seen a lot of the country but Seville is now by far my favorite place in Spain!

Overall the trip was what we thought it would be. However there were things that we did not expect, such as the amount of litter there was in the most popular parts of the city. Also very few smiles from spaniards who were reliant on the tourist trade and who gave the impressin that they would rather be some where else. It is a very beautiful place but very expensive when eating and drinking out.

column2: “Sevilla is... the love of a lifetime”
column3: Sevilla is... the love of a lifetime, so seductive that is impossible not to get back! Full of history and traditions, it molds itself to the inevitable modernity of the city, a unique combination of its arabic, spanish and, of course, european influences. It is a city with its own rhythm, where there's room for everyone: happiness, religiosity, flamenco, bulls, horses, living in a unique setting between the river Guadalquivir, the Barrio de Santa Cruz, the genuine Triana, Plaza de España, the Cathedral and the (long) Giralda, the Reales Alcazares and the Maestranza, and in April, the inevitable Feria!The time for a 'siesta' and 'tapas' is sacred, so in Seville, be Sevillian! Nos vamos a Sevilla?

Beautiful city. Very reasonable prices for food and drinks. A late night city with a definite culture. Elegant natives with beautiful children. Families meet on mass. Food very Spanish with little influence of junk food and pizzas . Lots of lovely tapas . Don't expect anything to cater for anything that is not Sevillano. The main cultural parts are in a small area and are easy to get around and very cheap to visit. There is plenty of walking so be prepared to walk miles and get lost down a maze of small streets. We used the train station .Very clean and very efficient and cheap. Best way to travel between cities.

We had the opportunity to visit Sevilla in November when our daughter was studying abroad in Spain. Sevilla is a charming city with a great deal of things to do and see. Absolutely loved the people, the food, the sights. Make sure you go to Triana neighborhood to visit the ceramic shops. Great shopping!!!
Seville, a great place to spend 2 -3 days. Lots to see and do here. Lovely architecture, easily walkable and the home of Flamenco!

Following a cruise from Malaga we had booked two nights in Seville. We travelled to Seville from Malaga by the excellent RENFE service which is punctual, clean and safe and there is a mass of taxis at the front entrance to the station which can take you to the old town for circa 7 or 8 euros. Our hotel was located in the old town beside the cathedral which was a great location with loads of bars and restaurants within walking distance.The city itself is wonderfully laid back with the Andalusian architecture and palm trees allied to temperatures in the mid-70's in late November and most of the major attractions can be covered on foot.There are excellent parks and museums dotted around the city with the main parks down from the University. Nightlife is good and there is a "safe" feel to the city. One recommendation is to take in a proper Flamenco show whilst you are there which I found fascinating despite it having never really appealed to me in the past - leaflets can be found at the tourist information offices.

Sevilla was simply marvelous.Very tight streets, Excellent Terrace Restaurants, Beautiful Weather, Excellent View from the Cathedral (Giralda) and the Reales Alcazares is very interestingI totally recommend it

column2: “Must visit city- Great people, Great food, great sightseeing”
