column3: Where do I start. My husband and I decided on spending our wedding anniversary in Europe this year. We did not want to go to all the typical places and that's why chose Spain. With the help of members on TA we decided on 3 cities out of which the highlight was of course seville.And what a wise choice we made. We spend 4 nights and 5 days in this wonderful city and experienced joy and beauty all around.We reached Seville, early morning- on the last day of Feria de Abril. Day one was spent enjoying the Feria, sipping sangria, clara limone and wine. We ended the evening by watching the awesome closing ceremony on the banks of Guadalquivir river and eating churroso.Day 2 we went around the town to the Plaza espana, Giralda, the Cathedral, The Real alcazar with lunch in one of the lil tapas places in barrio santa cruz distt. We spend the evening shopping and then exploring The Triana Distt.Day 3 we took a bus to Santi ponce and got down in the quaint town of ITALICA. It was great exploring the centuries old Roman Ruins. We spend the evening getting lost in the narrow and colorful streets of Barrio santa cruz distt. Everything was magical around the giralda area, a guy was playing Titanic theme track on violin and it was like being transported into dreams...Day 4: we just relaxed and shopped and ate loads of tapas and took walks around the city.Seville is a beautiful city with so much heritage and warmth. A great public transport system and warn & helpful people every ready to help.

Sevilla is romantic and beatifull.Stay at the margins of the river in a good hotel and walk every end of the day with the red sun!I must see: the flamenco shows ( Arenal, Los Gallos and Museo del Flamenco).Buy in El Corte Ingles: 10% of discount to tourist that came out of Spain, plus Tax Free.Enjoy!

I remember my time here fondly. I lived in Sevilla with a sassy older woman as a 'host mother' for 6 months. The city itself is full of hidden treasures and incredible niches upon which to stumble. El centro, the major downtown area, as its name suggests, is the center of the city. It's near the river (Guadalquivir) and is easily identified by the cathedral and many plazas. The two major shopping streets which adjoin are rivaled by few other areas in smaller European cities. My favorite part about the city was lounging by the river or trying out the many tapas restaurants in the area. It really is the heart of Spanish culture and everyone there will be sure to remind you of it. The many cafes and restaurants on the main strip are a must visit. Additionally, Plaza Alfalfa and Plaza Hercules (which may require a map for navigation) boast some off-the-beaten track bars and prime areas for people watching. Best times of the year to visit are the spring and fall, when the weather is not overbearingly hot or cold, and festivals occur every weekend.

column2: “Wonderful place to visit - allow more than a day if possible.”
column3: Unfortunately, we only had 5 hours in Seville, as we had a 4 hour bus ride there and back. We had to pick our sites. Based on Frommers, we went to the Alacazar, which is an amazing place to visit (although not as amazing as the Alhambra in Granada). We also went to the Cathedral, but with hindsight, we would rather have walked around more, and are sorry we didn't have time for the Barrio Santa Cruz. Ideally, it would be great to spend 2 - 3 days there. We also stopped for tapas and sangria, which were the best we had all week!Wish we were able to spend more time there. We would definitely go back!

Seville, or Sevilla, is one of the most authentic and charming cities that I've visited in Europe. The variety of places and historic sites that are easily accessible by foot, or bus, are complemented by the warmth and friendliness of its residents and the delicious food.Tapas, which are small dishes of either olives, curated ham (jamon serrano), fried fish (boquerones or adobo - I highly recommend adobo), Manchego cheese, anchovies, etc., are usually ordered and shared among a group around the table. These plates, though small, are very filling and very economical for the budget traveler. If you go in the Summer, try the Tinto de Verano, red wine mixed with soda. It is refreshing in the intense Summer heat of Seville.Sites to visit: The Cathedral and Giralda tower, Plaza España and Parque de Maria Luisa, the Royal Alcazar and gardens, Barrio de Santa Cruz, and the University of Seville (a former cigar factory which inspired the opera Carmen). The museums of Archeology and Arts & Customs are very interesting, and they are located in the Parque de Maria Luisa. Stroll along the Guadalquivir River and see the Torre del Oro, walk through the narrow streets around Barrio de Santa Cruz, watch a Flamenco show, and eat an ice cream at Mamá Goye. This place is located at the Plaza de Santiago, which also has a lot of night life during the Summer.The best time to visit Seville is in April, during the Feria. However, April is high season and hotel prices are at their highest during this time. Although hot, the months of July and September offer a very lively night life in the corners of charming Sevilla.

Just spent a week in Seville with my husband, Mum and Dad. We all loved it. Once you get to the old town - it is just beautiful and great weather as a bonus!! The river cruise is relaxing and the Alcazar amazing, Bario Santa Cruise is wonderful to explore and the ever present Giralda and Cathedral must be seen lit up at night! More than that though is the relaxed pace, frendly locals, amazing choice of places to eat and we found it to be very reasonable. There was much much more that we didnt have time to do, but we look forward to doing that next time!!

column2: “Sevilla, the most beautiful and charming city in Spain”
column3: Sevilla is a marvelous city that has great beauty, history, many cultures, many tourists and immigrants, amazing people, the one and only Giralda and one of the largest and most impressive gothic cathedrals in the world. It has cable cars, horses, the RIver Guadalquivir, great bars and cafes, impressive plazas all over, many many beautiful churches from different centuries, street vendors, so many narrow and beautiful streets and buildings from other eras, a large and very green park called Parque Maria Luisa, the Cartuja, the Barrio Santa Cruz (Old Jewish Quarter), la Iglesia del Salvador which is gorgeous, tapas to choose from, a fine Museo de Bellas Artes, the old but beautful Teatrio de Lope de Vega, the opera at the Teatro de la Maestranza, and of course, there is the old Tabacalera of "Carmen", now the University of Seville, and great flamenco to be found in Triana and at La Casa de la Memoria and the Carboneria and other places. as well as in many festivals in the summer. Sevilla's Jardines del Alcazar are competition with the Alhambra and must not be missed, and then there is the place for sweets,--La Campana; the Calle Sierpes, and of course, two stores I like: FNAC and Corte Ingles. Ah, Sevilla, you are also the only city I know where the tranvias play classical music. How nice and how classy. Sevillanos also have a keen sense of humor.Come experience Sevilla.

In this city in the south of Spain has plenty to offer. First, this city is well known for the flamenco dancing, it's a must see while in town. While in Seville, make sure to visit the outer neighorhoods away from the tourists. Stroll through the local parks, shops, and coffee shops being apart of the mix the locals.Enjoy

We just returned from a Trans-Altantic cruise on the HAL Noordam which stopped in the port of Cadiz, and offered us a chance for a day trip to Seville. We were initially hesitant to make the trip given the distance, but can only say thank godness we did. This city is truely one of the gems of Spain and not to be missed if you have a chance to pass through. Is one day enough to see it all? No it isn't, but what you'll get to see if you have a good guide will be well worth the trip and have you thinking about a return trip!We were fortunate to have booked a private tour through SpainDayTours as they provided us with a wonderful guide (Fernando) to the city as well as an escort (Xavier) to see to the group needs from the port and through the city. If you are considering a day tour, I would highly recommend them as I'm sure the other 15 participants from the Cruise Critic Roll Call for the voyage would also.Hope this helps you make a better decision on where to go!

This report was originally written to be posted as a blog article so it’s a bit chatty but gets the message across about our experiences in Seville (all positive, I might add).Just as the trip to New York was my birthday present from my wife, so our recent weekend trip to the Andalusian capital of Seville was my present to her for her birthday this year. When we left, the weather in the UK was pretty dismal so the prospect of a few sunny days in the warmth and sunshine was more than a little appealing. Not to mention the rioja, the fino wine, the chorizo, the Iberian cured meats and all the other goodies we were anticipating during our stay.Initially, I’d been a tad disappointed that the flight – at 17:00, or thereabouts, early on the Friday evening – hadn’t been earlier in the day, to make more of a day in Spain. As it turned out, though, it gave us ample opportunity to pack and travel to Heathrow’s terminal 3 for our flight and made for a very chilled out day. The flight was with Iberia, or Vueling, and I can highly recommend them – no frills, certainly, but they do exactly what they say “on the tin” and the flight was very enjoyable, if a tad on the warm side … for whatever reason, the plane was hot as the hobs of hell to the extent that the cabin crew were serving ice in the white wine to cool it off! Actually, quite a refreshing drink.We flew direct to Seville and as the airport is only a few miles outside the city the taxi transfer to our hotel in the heart of La Macarena, the most Northerly of the city’s 5 districts, the transfer to the hotel only took about 20 minutes and only costs approximately 25 €, though at weekends the price does increase.I can highly recommend the San Gil. The hotel staff were all extremely friendly and helpful and the hotel room was lovely. The hotel is built around the four sides of a central courtyard where there are orange trees, full of oranges and blossom, and where there is live entertainment – flamenco dancing – each night of the week except Sunday. Our room overlooked the central courtyard and was very comfortable, very clean and well equipped, with a big bathroom and good shower.Amongst the other things to recommend it is that many of the Spanish locals and Spanish visitors seemed to dine at the hotel, which always seems to me to be a very good endorsement of a place. On our first night at the San Gil, we wandered down to the bar and as we were tired decided to eat in the hotel and asked the barman for his recommendation, which he was only too pleased to give. It was delicious. The local custom is to eat the main meal of the day at lunchtime and then have a light meal, often of tapas, in the evening.Dinner started with a glass of fino wine, served chilled directly from the fridge, with olives and a selection of tapas. It continued with a bottle of very nice rioja and a plate of what, to me, is one of the nicest local delicacies – manchego cured cheese, a selection of Iberian cured meats and some chorizo. Interestingly, the wine was served chilled to 10 degrees as opposed to allowing it to breathe at room temperature, as is the custom in the UK – a concession to the warmth of the Andalusian climate. The evening concluded with a very hearty Spanish brandy in the hotel bar, where we discussed the varying fortunes of Ferrari’s driver Alonso in the recent Australian Grand Prix. We didn’t really have the heart to confess to being McLaren fans!Seville is a very compact city, built mainly on the Eastern bank of the Guadalquivir river and as it’s so compact, it’s more than feasible to see the city on foot. This would be my recommendation to anyone who’s fit and able. Seeing the city on foot is undoubtedly the best way to experience the streets, lined with red, yellow and ochre buildings, and the life of the city at close hand.There are tour buses available and, round the cathedral and the Parque Maria Luisa, horse-drawn carriages but neither of them can get to the same “nooks and crannies” of the city as you can on Shanks’s pony.We walked through the streets of La Macarena, taking in the sights and sounds, passing the market building with it’s fish market, fruit and veg stalls and butchers, with their hanging bunches of chorizo sausages (a personal favourite of mine), and making our way towards the Eastern district of Santa Cruz, where some of the more famous buildings of the city are located.The city clearly shows it’s Moorish history and the results of the Christian Reconquista in many of the churches, which are on the sites of former mosques, many still retaining the Moorish courtyards with orange trees, full of blossom and fruit at this time of year, where the Muslim visitors to the mosques would have washed before prayer. The huge gothic cathedral at the heart of the Santa Cruz district is no exception and also boasts the impressive bell tower, La Giralda, which was formerly the minaret for the mosque that occupied the site but was subsequently repurposed with the removal of the Muslim symbols from the top and the addition of a Christian bell tower complete with the statue of El Giraldillo, representing Faith, topping the structure.Visiting the cathedral is a must – the interior is very impressive and highly ornate and amongst the many beautiful items of church paraphernalia and works of art it houses the tomb of Christopher Columbus and a truly spectacular area around the high altar.Across the Plaza Virgen de los Reyes from the cathedral is the Real Alcazar, or Royal Palace, which is awash with beautiful architecture, decorated with intricate ceramic designs, and peaceful courtyards. Sitting on the highly decorated stone benches, covered with ceramic tiles, on a warm, sunny afternoon (the weather was 25 degrees and sunny throughout our stay in the city) was a lovely relaxing experience. I could’ve stayed there all day!I’ve already mentioned the tapas-based meal we had on our first evening in the hotel but at lunch times we were able to satisfy my craving for one of my other favourite dishes, paella. Freshly made, of course, it took a little while to come but the waiter told us when we ordered that there’d be a delay of about 20 minutes while it was prepared and so we were quite happy to sit and sip sangria and munch our way through the fresh bread provided for us. It was worth the wait. A small table was drawn up alongside our own and the waiter brought the paella dish there and served it onto our plates. Delicious … and large! We had two full platefuls each!Our final day in the city was spent exploring the Parque Maria Luisa and the Plaza de Espana, a truly impressive building on the edge of the park that was built for the 1929 Ibero-American Exposition. This Southern area of the city was completely re-developed into an extensive park, full of beautiful formal gardens and tiled fountains, planted on land donated to the city of Seville by the Duchess of Montpensier, Princess Maria Luisa Fernanda de Orleans from whom the park gains its name, in the late 19th century.We only had two full days plus one half day in Seville and, to be fair, it wasn’t enough! I’d recommend the city to anyone and was sad to leave as I loved every aspect of our stay – the architecture, the lifestyle, the food, the atmosphere and, of course, the lovely warm weather – I would’ve loved to stay for longer, if I could.

We have just returned from 5 days at Seville's Semana Santa. despite misgivings we found that while it was exceptionally busy there was still plenty of room for us. The bar tenders were tolerant of our lack of fluency, the food was excellent and reasonably priced and the people were oh so friendly. The streets were cleaned daily. There was some disruption to our plans when the trams and buses stopped for the duration of some processions but despite the crowds we did not feel the least bit threatened. The left luggage at the Prado bus station was a godsend and the Real Alcazar let us in free of charge as we are over 65. Go for it - it is an amazing spectacle.

For first time visitors to Seville, a Flamenco Show is a must.There are many available, we recently went to Seville (Dec./Jan. 2009/2010) and saw several shows. This is our opinion:The Best by far for the Show is : Tableo El Patio Sevillano, and here is their website: http://www.elpatiosevillano.com There is a large cast, on a bright/large stage. The dancing is fantasic, the singing very impressive (well one singer was incredible), the dresses and general 'show' all combined to make a great experience... HIGHLY RECOMMENDED.Some other details:Some shows in Seville are for free (you get what you pay for).If you leave it up to the hotel front desk then you might get the show that they have the best arrangement with (one hotel we stayed in (we stayed in two) claim to never have heard of the place above???Several 'shows' offer packages like show+drink, or show+tapas or show+dinner. Expect to pay 35-40 euros each for show+drink, and more (much more?) for food options. Most that we went to were very busy and it is smart to reserve places even in low season.As an alternative, we also saw "El Arenal" (http://www.tablaoelarenal.com/), the price about the same, the show was not even close in quality of Flamenco... fewer dancers, smaller stage, the singers were nothing to be impressed about - however it was very nice place, nicely decorated and the food looked good (we did not eat there).

Seville is one of those places that you can't get enough of. There's always something new to discover - a narrow street, a tapas bar, beautiful architecture. Seville does have some quirks that at first pass can be quite annoying but after time, you realize that's what makes Seville so unique and special. Each time I return from a trip from Seville I long for the next time I can book my return visit.

Sevilla is a beautiful city, full of color and history. The gardens and parks are glorious. Lots of people there, enjoying the sun and flowers. Watch for gypsies selling you sprigs of rosemary for "luck" - they don't take coins, so they will try to stick you with a sprig and expect 5 euros! best to just walk away or don't acknowledge them.Be sure to take in the museum of bullfighting and the bullring tour!The cathedral where Christopher Columbus is buried was closed the afternoon we were there, so check ahead of time if you want to see it.

column2: “Arabic Baths and good food in Seville.”
column3: The Arabic baths were amazing. Now, the one we went to was on Aire, a small, narrow passage not far from the cathedral. Here is the website http://www.airedesevilla.com/It was 20 euro for 1 hour and a half in there and you are told when you arrive how it all works and where to go etc....you can pay extra for a massage. When the thrapist is ready for you she will come and find you. You don't need to take a towel, they have all that...just a swimsuit. Now when you go, you may have a small wait because they send people in a few a time...say 15 people at 2pm for example and then another 15 at 3.30 pm. This is good though...it doesn't get at all busy then.The good food place we found is directly opposite the cathedral, just a bit further up from the 1st Starbucks. It's like a place full of old fashioned counters, a bit like the Harrods food hall. You can eat in (don't bother) or get 'take away' and sit on the cathedral steps (cheekily) opposite their outdoor eating area. Much nicer!Go to the tapas counter and ask for a small amount of a few different things. They have small plastic containers and cutelry. It was yummy, we had loads and paid only 5 or 6 euros each. They also do baguettes and things but I wouldn't bother! go with the tapas picnic. Oh and their mint ice cream too....... :)Now, on an evening try this restaurant at the end of the Puente de san Telmo bridge. It has outdoor tables overlooking the river, the house white and beer is good and the food GENEROUS! A large anything is more than enough for 2 or 3 to share. Spacious, friendly staff and no rush to pay and leave.It is not the end of the bridge where the tower is by the main road but the other end.....by the Plaza De Cuba. Very easy to find and you can jump off the bus near the bridge if you are coming from the hotel which we stayed at. It is the 1st restaurant you come to ....something Giardino....something to do do with a garden maybe...can't remember the name!Let me know if you need any more info!

First of all, Seville is HOT in the summer. But there is a good side to this: not too many people around in August. Downtown Seville is pretty small and it was nice to walk the streets when they were a bit less crowded.The hotel was affordable and great: Hotel Alminar. Maria was great, helped me with some Wifi problems on my Mac and gave me some very good recommendations which I will now pass along to you!The restaurant Vineria San Telmo was very, very good and the prices a steal. The best tapas restaurant I've been to in a long time! Extremely friendly, very good wines by the glass and LOTS of nice tapas.As Maria told me, I went to the Alcazar right when it opened in the morning. Even in quiet August, this made a difference as this magnificent old palace began to fill up with other visitors about an hour after I showed up.Maria also recommended a flamenco performance held regularly in a beautiful little courtyard nearby, attached to the Casa de la Memoria. I'm glad I went! Memorable.

A short review of our recent visit to SevillaWe flew with Ryanair from LIverpool into Sevilla and took the coach into the city 2.30 euro each way, last stop near Murillo gardens was ideal, about a 15 min walk to Hotel Murillo, a great hotel, clean, tidy, quiet and very helpful reception, down one of the very narrow streets in the Santa Cruz old town area, just a few minutes from the Alcazar and Catherdral, we stayed for 4 nights.Arriving early afternoon gave us time to explore and get our bearings, the next day we spent walking throughout the city taking in the river and many of the churchs, we ate at one of the number of restrauntes in Santa Cruz.Next day we visited the Real Alcazar, well worth a visit, amazing how much there is to see, well maintained throughout, the royal family still use the palace, we didnt but for exta 4.20 you can visit the private quaters, certainly as good as the Alhambra, large gardens and a great little cafe!Next day we walked to Santa Justa train station about 30 mins from Santa Cruz caught the 9am Express train to Cordoba, the AVE takes half the time and gives you more time options but costs three times as much, our two returns on the Express were 31 euros.Cordoba is a great visit, the catherral is an absolute must, unfortunately the Alcazar closed at 2.30pm so we missed that one, had a good walk around the many lovely little streets and across the river - lot of work around the rivers edge, Cordoba is the capital of culture 2016.On our final day we did the cathderal and and tower in Sevilla again a visit well worth reccomendation, and to the above a little shopping we had an excellent trip if a little on the hot side - upto 43c at times in the last week of August.

There is just not enough words to describe the absolute beauty of this city! We stayed near the Old Jewish Quarter at the Hotel Becquer (awesome), which was walking distance to the Cathedral (Christopher Columbus' Tomb is there), Alcazar (Where the voyage to America was planned), Bull Fighting Ring, quaint sidewalk cafes and Tapas bars, cobblestone streets, etc., etc, .

Sevilla has both old and new charm. It is a friendly, walkable, decently priced, clean city and we were sorry we only had 2 days there! We stayed at Le Petit Palace Canalejas, which is a lovely old architectural building, but the inside is completely "high-tech" with a lap top in each room and suprising comforts like a hydro massage shower! Decent rates-- we got a 10% discount for staying 3 nights.

Although being portuguese, I'm a real passionate of spanish culture; so living side by side with Spain, I frequently visit spanish citys.Sevilla is one of the spanish city's that touched me the most: vibrant, attractive, graceful and most of all... historically rich. The weather is something to think about before going: if you don't like heat, avoid summer months. I choose the Carnival weekend, and February went out to be warm during the day and cool at night, just perfect to walk.Sevilla is the symbol of the spanish navigation conquist, where Colombo (Colón/Columbus) heard his wanted Yes from Isabel at the Real Alcazar and started his journey, specifically at Guadalquivir River, to America. The Torre del Oro, a golden tower, still stands vigilant over the river. The Cathedral is one the most magestic in all world, enhanced by the Giralda's Tower, required spot to take a panoramic view of the city. Inside the Cathedral, I have to mention, the magnific central Nave and the two Organs, the full-of-gold Altar and of course... the Colombo's Tomb, where the great Explorer stands in his eternal sleep.Walking throughout Sevilla's old city is another 'must do'. The narrow streets with tall, coloured and well decorated old Palace-House's facades, with their flowering pateos (terraces) and amazing gates, full of handcraft stores and tapas bars (bodeguitas)... you are at the mitical Bairro Santa Cruz . Another quarter that worths visit is the Bairro Arenal, with more wide and comercial streets, and Bairro da Triana, at the other side of the river, where tipical handmade ceramics is available.Calle Sierpes and Calle Tetuan are the most trendy streets of the city, where the Flamenco culture emerges at every store, in the form of coloured and glamourous dresses, shoes, hats and abanicos (tipical fans).The Plaza de España is another attraction; far from centre, in a 15 minutes walking distance, really worths visiting for great photos. It's a large and magnifical open square, crossed by ornamented bridges over the cannal, complemented by a half-moon magestic building at one of the sides.The food is another attraction: eat everything, at the bars and bodeguitas, from montaditos (little sandwiches), to tapas or raciones, with lots of olive oil, tommato and iberian ham, well accompanied by cañas (local beer) or sangria (sweet fruited red wine, served on a jar).I just loved Sevilla.

Seville,Went with a group of friends (16) stayed in the centre of Seville. Hotel Becquer, very nice, close to the centre and within walking distance of the sites.Cathedral well worth the entrance fee. Take the walk up the tower can be hard going but well worth the effort.Super little resturants all about, reasonable shopping, the Bull ring is quite interesting, even without the fighting, small museum to see.We took the open top bus tour and it was OK, but a little sparse on venues.Most of the action is in and around the centre of the town, weekend break would do the lot. But nice atmosphere and friendly.Generally an OK visit.

column2: “A place to avoid near the Seville (Sevilla) Catherdral”
column3: SUMMARY: Food is OK to POOR. SERVICE is POOR to RUDE. Do the world a favor and do not patronize places like this.LONG VERSION: We've been on a week-long vacation in Spain, including stays in Madrid, Granada and Seville (Sevilla). Those who have spent time in Madrid and Sevilla know that the loval have lunch around 3 PM and dinner around 10. In fact, on our first day here, we couldn't get into the first 5 Madrid restaurants we visited at 10:30PM as they were either full, or had reserved tables yet to arrive!!We've been fortunate to visit our daughter who is on a "study abroad" semester with full Spanish immersion and is fluent in Spanish. I mention this to cover to potential communication issues when at a restaurant - our situation was purely a result of the restaurant service.We were greeted warmly at Bar Gonzalo (near the catherdral)when we entered at 10PM on a Friday evening (this is not late for a Madrid or Sevilla dinner as mentioned above). We promptly ordered a nice bottle of wine, the pollo arroyo, and a mixed paella. The drinks arrived promptly and were good. The chicken also arrived promptly - VERY promptly. But no paella. 10 minutes, 20 minutes. Finally a member of the suddenly absent wait staff came by to mention that paella took longer to cook than chicken (while obviously a fact, not a real reason for our situation).About 40-50 minutes later, the rest of the meal arrived - barely cooked, poor quality seafood ... after struggling through part of the this final dish, a new waitress arrived and started banging the shutters very loudly, and otherwise closing the place down. She was very rudely encouraging us to leave - when surprisingly we had wanted to leave a half hour earlier if only our food could have arrived in some reasonable time. My 9-year old daughter said the wait staff were "giant craps" and I really had no basis to refute that assessment.

Experience in Andalucia SevillaSimply I love Sevilla....during the day ,during the night, with comerce with hostelerii with Triana so gypsy created by goodness who made this part of city not to be discovered ther by Hercules falling love to her.I love Seville with muesuems as well as a market of picture during sunday morning. Los Remedios with tabaccos factory and shops and University old building full of history of Carmen. AS well I like Barbier from Seville.I love el puente over river in the street BETIS....same I like beaches, ceramics, ocean and sea.Flamenco, tapas, beer, vine....a lot of stufs wich I forget.I thnik Andalucia and Seville is what we are calling typical spanish.

I followed the recommendations and can confirm that if you want to see Flamenco go to this show.I have seen the occasional show on previous visits around Spain, but this show seriously is what it states on the tin "Traditional Flamenco."Quite simply it was well worth both the time finding it and the cost. But, as other have indicated, book first and get their at least 30 mins early and queue for a front seat, its well worth it.

Seville is in the south of Spain. It is a beautiful city. It is full of history. The streets are very narrow. There are humble people.You have to be careful with the streets that have gypsies.Had fun!

Sevilla is a great place to relax and see what Southern Spanish life is all about. You can see everything in a day and a half, but it makes a great stop on the way to Cordoba or Granada. Be sure and see the Cathedral and Alcazar. We also went to the Banos Arabes and it was a great way to relax, while still enjoying the ambiance of Sevilla

we Traveled both ways via Madrid which has a fantastic airport but both flights were delayedThe city has beautiful buildings with gems around every corner in the old paved townOnly one tram line as yet but as it goes past all the main tourist sights great value at 1,10E a tripfrom the centre to the Plaza de Espagne as seen in star warswe walked a lot and found it a delight with the main shops open until 10 at night and the rest until latedark about 7 pm so nice to walk around the lit up streetsWe found the meals in the restaurants rather to big and very rich with lots of sauces and they open lateTabernas are an option with lighter menus and open all dayFabulous fish restaurantsand lots of Tapas bars smaller portions and much favoured by the locals served with beersand cakeshops to die forFull of Spanish ladies choosing and eating with knives and forksThe hot chocolate you can eat with a spoon and you must try the churros to dip in at least onceThe tourist places are well knownand most enjoyable in small doses on a warm dayit got to 24 last week in FebruaryWe visited one place a day with a day off for shoppingIt must be remembered no shops open on Sundays or bank holidaysVery little English is spoken unlike the Costas and even with French and English and some spanish we still needed to wave our arms aroundWell worth having something with your age on if over 65 or retired the entrance prices for the monuments are very much less or even freeHard on the feet ,air on the purse and to be seen at least once

column2: “The City with only one single bicyclingpath”
column3: I fell in love with Seville on a sunny day in april '06. I borrowed a mountainbike from Sara, the flatmate of my friend Juande. Juande and his classmate, Juanma, wanted to show me the city biking. I'll never forget how we drove across crowded streets and walkingpaths. The two guys drove as if there were no traffic around us. There were! Actually the traffic was everywhere. And the streets where filled with crowds of people, celebrating the holy Semana Santa. But fact was, that there only appeared one single circle of bicyclingpath in the whole center of Seville. So we drove slalom between cars and parades of Semana Santas. It was unbelievable. We were probably the only ones bicycling that day. But it was fun.Another thing that amazed me is the huge underground-culture behind the facade. Well, I guess that most cities of the world have this so called "underground-life". It's just a matter of getting introduced to it. You have to know someone or meet somebody who can introduce you. This leads me back to Juandes flatmate Sara. An interesting and special girl. She is studying art at the university of Seville. She and her amiga, Liz, took me out some nights at places and nightclubs I would never have experienced without knowing them. Basements with dancing freaks and Lou Reed on the sterio. toilets with no toilets??? painted faces, smells of marihuana and sweat, barefooted gyus, chilling out on thye edge of the dancefloor and an atmosphere undescribeable.Then not to forget the huge park near the university. Mainly a place for the studens to hang around, play football or have a nap. Orangetrees everywhere, and the smell of them. Parents with their children, groups of teenagers with their bikes, smoking cigarettes.All these things, in many ways similar to other big cities in the world, but in a spanish way that I fell in love with.

column2: “seville - dona maria hotel - plus the segway tour is a must!”
column3: My boyfriend and i went to seville on a mini break - and we had a lovely time - a great city to explore on foot. Or... on a segway! - we discovered a small segway tour guide company and had a blast - scooting past all the tourists on our new favourite mode of transport!the city is beautiful - and has lots to offer a couple/family for a weekend away.Very safe and clean - however a spanish phase book is a must!we recommend the bodega tapas bar - located around the corner from the cathedral, an open fronted bar - with some great locals enjoying the warm evenings.we stayed at the Dona Maria hotel - which is a ace location - although the hotel rooms are slightly dated.The only drawback of the location is the bells waking you up each morning as you are so close to the cathedral.
A delightful way to spend an hour. But do not use the ones around the Cathedral, they are more expensive. The carriages along the river are cheaper and last longer

There is just too much to say about this wonderful place. 6 days were not enough for me. I did 3 walking tours with Concepcion at www.sevillawalkingtours.com and these were very good as i was alone and it was nice to be part of a group. Everyone was so friendly, I have never felt so safe in a city anywhere in the world. The food was superb and a beer as I sat in the sunshine watching the children on a Sunday with a view of the river was simply heaven. The smell of orange blossom in the warm sunshine was breathtaking. There is too much to say except I will certainly go back. Hopefully the photos will say it all.

I had very high expectations when I arrived in Sevilla. I have never heard anyone say anything negative about the city. We took a bullet train from Madrid and it was a rather fun experience. I could not really say the same thing about the city...We stayed at a 5-star hotel. We only dined in the restaurants recommended by friends or the well-known guide books. We saw almost all famous tourist sites/gardens/shows. Nevertheless, the experience was always only average at the most. I still do not understand why people love Sevilla so much.They do have the best flamenco dancers in Spain, I'll give them that. But that was about the only thing that impressed me there. If you are in Spain, visit Barcelona, Madrid, Ronda, Granada, Toledo, and maybe Malaga. Sevilla should not be on your "must see" list.

We have just returned from a 5 day visit to Seville and as I have used this forum for advice on previous occasions I thought I would pass on my experiences while thereWe (Two grandparents, two parents and two children aged 15 and 13) stayed at the Hotel Vime Corregidor, I had read that it had been refurbished and indeed it was extremely clean and comfortable. I had also read about the rude man on reception but luckily all my dealings were with two very helpful and polite young ladies. The rooms are fine with air conditioning and a flat screen tv on the wall showing Spanish programming along with sky news and BBC world news, the double (room 101) consisted of two separate beds pushed together and the twin rooms also had two beds pushed together, the only difference was the double was slightly roomier, especially the bathroom which had more room to lay out your toiletries Breakfast was fine with a good selection of cereals, cold meats, fruit, and hot scrambled eggs, sausages etc, ideal to start off the day before a lot of walking; I have to say I would be happy to stay here againWith regards to the work been done around Seville, yes there is major construction going on in the city, but it did not spoil our holiday in any way (although the rain certainly tried) the majority of Seville is just fineI have included a couple of pictures to show what I felt was the worst of the building going on. The entire length of Avenida De La Constitution has been excavated as has Plaza Nueva, however access along the side of the road is still possible as a pathway has been kept clear and access to all the businesses and bars is still possible, the works in no way affects the Cathedral / Alcazar area or the warren of streets that surround themWe really did walk for miles, this is a city that should be seen on foot, the narrow streets open out into small plazas with lovely churches on almost every corner and a bar or café to rest in for 5 minutes (or longer), by the way, be prepared to step into a doorway when a vehicle comes along as some of the streets really are narrow in places, some of the buses go down roads I would hesitate to drive down in a MiniA couple of places I would recommend (other than the obvious Cathedral and Alcazar) are:Flamenco show at Casa de la Memoria, Calle Ximenez de Encisco 28, 41004, Sevilla, (If you look at a map it is a road slightly north east of the Real Alcazar) The show lasts for an hour and is breathtaking, it starts with a guitarist and singer performing a traditional song and then a male and female dancer join the show, the dancers put everything they have into the show and I cannot do it justice here, If you want to experience flamenco then do not miss this show, it was one of the highlights of our trip, definitely pre book either the day before or on the morning of the showA visit to the Bullring, a tour takes only 20 minutes and shows you the bullring itself, the Chapel, Infirmary, and a small museum, it was enough for me to realise I would not like to see the real thing but was interesting none the lessCasa De Pilatos, so named because it is thought to resemble the home of Pontius Pilate in Jerusalem, much like the Real Alcazar the rooms are mainly empty, I found it strange that a lot of places were empty of furniture but was told that it was because the main extravagance and therefore cost went on the wall and ceiling decorations which are the main attractions (I must admit they are very good) and the subsequent looting and removal of furniture and works of art throughout the ages As with the Real Alcazar the Gardens were lovely and worth visiting in there own right, as a footnote we had no problems with insects until we visited the gardens, at the Real Alcazar I became meal of the day for the local biting insects in the gardens and experienced to slightly lesser extent the same hereDay trip to Jerez de la Frontera (Just over an hour away on the train) to visit the ‘Fundation Real Escuela Andaluza Del Arte Equestre’ even if you are not a horse lover this show is still worth seeing, the horses and riders are so graceful to watch, the show demonstrates most aspects of horse riding (Although there is no mad charging about, it is very formal and stately) from the trot & canter to the Spanish walk, piaffe and pirouette, there is also a demonstration of carriage riding , the show starts at 12 noon and lasts about an hour and ten minutes with a short break in the middle, this leaves enough time for a visit to one of the many sherry houses in the area for a tour (and tasting) before catching the train back to SevilleFor shopping definitely visit Call. Sierpes, and Calle. Velasquez Tetuan which run parallel to each other and are full of fine designer shops to visit as well as more well known stores and ceramic shops, for those who are staying in central Seville on a self catering basis we did not see a lot of places to buy your daily needs as you would in the uk from one large store, it seems to be small shops such as a fishmonger’s, grocers etc scattered around in widely dispersed places although I am sure the locals would be able to point out any number of places. However on our last day we found an ‘El Corte Ingles’ much like a Debenhams in England and in the basement is the largest supermercado you could hope to find selling everything from English teabags upwards, it can be found In the immediate area of Calle.Velasquez Tetuan we wandered down one of the side streets and there it was, the actual road it was on may have been called Calle. Mendez Nunez but I am not 100 percent sureFood in Seville, I am quite adventurous and will try most things, however having teenage children with us (and a family who could live on chicken and chips) made things a little more difficult, sadly the general family consensus on Tapas was UURGGGHHH! I happened to like the beans and pork and dishes of Olives and pickled beans etc that arrived, I must admit that being navigator I dragged them to local, out of the way places where we and the proprietor could not understand a word of what we were saying to each other and resorted to pointing at the menu board and saying Tapas for 6! I thought we did quite well but I was in a definite minority If you should find yourself in a similar situation I can heartily recommend Flaherty’s Irish Bar, it is on Calle. Alemanes which runs along the north side of the Cathedral and will serve you a really good selection of food, from an all day Irish breakfast to chicken and chips, Ribs, Burgers, Wraps & Salads, it was a definite hit with the kids as well as adults with the bonus of a pint of Guinness I would also recommend a good restaurant called ‘Horno De San Buenventura’ it is on the corner of Garcia De Vinuesa where it meets Ave. De la Constitution (not far from Flaherty’s), it looks from the outside like a smart delicatessen / pastry shop and believe me it does fantastic cakes to eat in or take away along with cold meats etc, downstairs is always busy with limited seating but go to the back and up the stairs and there is plenty of seating for a family to relax and eat in comfortI hope this may have been of some help to any readers, I feel like I have left out such a lot but this is turning into a marathon and I do not want to ramble on too muchEnjoy your visit to Seville

I loved this city. There was so much more to see than I had expected. If you love historic cities that at the same time are still alive, this is a city for you. I enjoyed walking the cobblestone streets, finding tiny churches tucked away in small plazas. The architecture is fantastic too. Of course, visiting the Alcazar is a must. This is an amazing monument, with gorgeous Moorish design, and beautiful gardens. The cathedral can't be missed either, being (I think) the largest Gothic cathedral in the world. It's also great to climb up to the top of the tower (originally a minaret from Moorish times) adjoining the cathedral for beautiful views of the city. I also enjoyed visiting Plaza de Espana. All in all, there's plenty to see and do in Seville. I'd say it's a wonderful place to spend about 4 or 5 days. Oh, and I also liked the weather. It was mid-October, so mornings and evenings were mild, with very warm afternoons. And what a beautiful, blue, cloudless sky, forming an amazing backdrop to the colorfully painted historic buildings. A truly beautiful, romantic city to visit.

We stayed at the San Andres Apartment (---). It was lovely, cozy and romantic with a big bed, two big terraces and a jacuzzi on the roof which is perfect for chilling out with a glass of wine at siesta time.The owner was lovely, she left a great hospitality basket and maps of plenty of useful recomendations ranging from food markets to flamenco.It is great value for money and I think much nicer than a hotel. It's about 20 minutes walk from the cathedral in a pleasant part of Seville.Highly recommended - we would go back tomorrow.

I stayed at a girlfriends house who lives near Seville! I was there in the week of 26th of april to 1st of may!! This week was the Feria there...this is a big party that takes one week...and you MUST have been there ones.My girlfriend had a different Flamenca-dress everyday and...she looked stunning. Like all the spanisch woman do in a flamenca dress!! For foreigners there are a few "casetta's" (big colorfull tents) to visit, but try to hook up wth a local, they are verry friendly and open and i am sure they will invite you for a cold drink!! I had a fantastic time, dancing, drinking, having fun untill the sun risses!!This sentence you must learn: una garr de rebujito, par favor!! When you say this to the bartender he will give you a typical Feria-drink you must try!!Have fun!

Along with about 80,000 Celtic fans, I went to Seville in May 2003 for the EUFA cup final. against Porto. At the time, I wasn`t bothered where the final was being played - I just wanted to be there! However, what a magical city it is. Full of North African architecture, mixed with Spanish hospitality and even palm trees, it truly was a fantastic experience.The city`s cathedral is an absolute must, as is, the bull ring, along with exploring the city`s many crooked, narrow streets. Even though I`m not a shopper (and shopping was the last thing on my mind) there were some excellent bargains to be had.I`m definitely going to visit again. Next time I`ll take the wife along for a romantic break - I can`t wait!! (ps Celtic lost, but the city won for me)

I went to Seville never having been to Spain, before I was there for 3 months and it was at first so strange.... but when I left I left my soul behind. Now I am going back for the third time....Do not worry if you bump into people on there way to wherever - they do not worry - stop and rest on the plazas and watch them hurrying buy. Take note of how they walk - with shoulders back and proud they smile more they laugh more they are wonderful people... Try and communicate in their language and you are soon accepted... If you dont try they will ignore you.. The city is a dream, bells ringing everywhere and so much to see....Go once and you will be hooked.. but watch out on the narrow little paths for dogs and Vespas.....

Seville was real spain after several years beach hols on the costas. Fab athmosphere, genuine place, easy to get around.We can very recommend the Patios De Sevilla apts to stay. (95 490 02 00). Casa Juderia also looks very good. Always book ahead!!! 1000 yrs of tourists cant be wrong...fiestas book a year ahead it seems.Lots to do... good pedestrian streets and great old centre. Certainly worth 2-3 days any month.Seville has good trains to everywhere.Hotels and restaurants are more expensive than in Jerez and Cadiz which are easy to get to, fascinating and worth at least a day trip or 2-3 days or so each.We also stayed at Hotel Monasterio in Puerto de Santa Maria ... and toured by car to Jerez, Cadiz (great shopping) and hillvillages etc. A 5 star hotel in an interesting town.

Nous avons séjourné avec des amis pendant 4 jours à Séville en mai 2015. La ville et très belle avec de nombreux monuments et églises à visiter. En mai les chaleurs sont étouffantes ( 39° sur les 4 jours déjà) mais la températures redescend assez rapidement vers 21h22h et on peut profiter des bars a tapas et de la vie nocturne sévillane.
Toda Sevilla es una preciosa y rabiosamente bella ciudad. Impresionante su Plaza de España!!!!Digna de verse, al igual que el Parque María Luisa y todo lo que ofrece esta señorial ciudad

We hebben een hele dag met de fiets Sevilla doorkruist. Een echte aanrader doordat er heel veel fietspaden zijn en nauwelijks heuvels. Bovendien heeft de stad heel erg veel te bieden en nadat wij op de eerste dag de hele stad hadden bekeken vanaf de fiets, konden we de dagen daarna enkele dingen wat langer en beter bekijken. Vergeet geen data-abonnement en Google Maps te installeren, want Sevilla heeft een eindeloze voorraad straatjes, steegjes en weggetjes die overal en nergens uitkomen. Maar met Google Maps is dat prima te doen.

Ausflug Sevilla: "Du bist nicht Stadt, sondern eine Welt ! ... Herakles hat mich gegründet, Caesar befestigt ... und der heilige König hat mich erobert, Sevilla." Wir besichtigen die prächtige Stadt mit der schönsten Kirche Spaniens, die Kathedrale Santa Maria, die als größter gotischer Dombau der christlichen Welt bezeichnet wird. Außerdem noch das frühere Königsschloss Acazar und die Altstadt mit ihren charakteristischen jüdischen Vierteln.

column2: “Recorriendo el casco antiguo de Sevilla, España. Real Alcázar”
column3: Estuve varios días en la ciudad de Sevilla, todo hermoso,su gente, y las actividades turísticas, por motivos de asistir a un congreso en la Universidad de Sevilla. Me alojé en la Residencia Universitaria de Estanislao del Campo, y aproveché varios días y a toda hora de recorrer diversos lugares atractivos que corresponden a su patrimonio tan importante. Les invito a conocer el Real Alcázar, varios palacios reunidos en este lugar, ubicados en pleno casco antiguo de Sevilla, de fácil llegada y acceso.

Nous avons aimés l'architecture des batiments aussi bien au coeur de ville qu'a l'extérieur. Ses rues très étroites, ses boutiques de robes typiques de flamenco, ses heladerias pas banales, ses tapas, ses places ornées de palmiers, la gentillesse et la serviabilité des Sévillans.Le moins : trop de calèches

Sevilha é a cidade onde a Espanha é mais espanhola. Isto porque conserva muitas das tradições e costumes vivos (Semana Santa, Feria, Touradas, Comidas típicas, etc). Suas atrações não se reduzem aos monumentos mais conhecidos, como a Giralda, o Alcazar e a Plaza España. Não deixe de visitar o Museu de Belas Artes, que só pela decoração já vale a visita, além de ir na Plaza Alfafa, Plaza de Encarnación (Setas). Também vale a visita aos Jardins de Murillo e aos Jardins de la Buhaira. Triana é o bairro ideal para apreciar o Flamenco e aproveitar os barzinhos. Além da Alameda de Hércules, praça mais antiga e mais bohemia da Europa. Conhecer Sevilha é andar por suas ruas, sobretudo as tradicionais Calle Feria (rua das feiras), Calles Sierpes e Tetuán (Centro), entre outras. O bairro de Santa Cruz é um dos mais bonitos e agradáveis, vale a visita ao Hospital de Los Venerables e nas diversas praças que concentra ao redor. Conhecer Sevilha é viver essa cidade maravilhosa. Ir aos banhos árabes, comer tapas e desfrutar de bons momentos a beira do Rio Guadalquivir. E se sobrar um tempinho, vale a pena conhecer Itálica, ali pertinho de Sevilha.
Cidade agradavel. Ficar hospedado no centro histórico eh a pedida! Facil de se locomover e com boa comida. Foi surpreendente

Me gusto el ambiente festivo. Dicen que son poco trabajadores. Yo los vi muy alegres y dispuestos para el turismo. Son muy simpaticos en su forma de hablar acentuando la ultima silaba de todas las palabras.
Es una ciudad que me ha impresionado, no esperaba que me gustara tanto, tiene muchas cosas que ver y hay mucho ambiente, tanto de turistas como de sevillanos. Además, se come muy bien y no es caro.

un viaggio azzeccato! bella città con numerose attrattive storiche! comoda da girare tranquillamente a piedi nonostante gli autobus siano numerosi e frequenti! cittadini gentilissimi i quali, se si accorgono che sei in difficoltà, sono i primi a fermarsi e a chiederti se hai bisogno di aiuto o spiegazioni! si respira un'aria allegra e serena! quanti ristorantini tipici e bar!!!!! da visitare!

Muito gostosa a cidade. Visite a Catedral, a Real Alcaza, Plaza de Toros e perca-se pelo Bairro Judeu... visite o bairro de Triana, praticamente uma outra cidade dentro da cidade. Não esqueça de ir a um show flamenco.

Citta ricca di storia e con molte cosa da visitare.Ha una vita notturna molto vivace.Ideale per tutti i tipi di viaggi sia con famiglia che con amici.Per la sua visita due tre giorni sono sufficienti.

Es una hermosa ciudad, con edificios muy bellos. No te pierdas la catedral y su minarete, la torre del oro, el puente Isabel II, divina la plaza España. La universidad está en el lugar en que funciono una fábrica de tabacos
Cidade muito gostosa. Pequena, porém completa. Clima bem ameno. Não perca um show de flamenco, característico da região e por sinal muito bonito.

La vieille ville est absolument charmante et il est possible de réaliser l'entièreté de votre citytrip à pieds.Séville regorge de cultures et d'endroits à découvrir ... pour flâner un peu ou se cultiver :-)
Aciertan los que califican Sevilla de una ciudad especial. Disfruté mucho la estancia. Muy recomendable comer marisco en Triana. Espectaculares las vistas desde el puente sobre el Guadalquivir.
il profumo di primavera e pulizia della città, oltre ai monumenti e flamenco; rilassante e tranquillatroppa enfasi sul cattolicesimo
santa cruz est un peu trop touristique, s'éloigner un peu vers Alfalfa et se perdre dans les ruelles et troquets nous a plu
Me encantó el barrio del Arenal y el ambiente en las calles .Todo el mundo estaba en las calles.Ciudad con mucha vida.
Кроме как в центре мы не были, но я бы туда вернулась еще раз. Приятные улочки, уютные кафе. Все располагает к отдыху.

Città viva ma tranquilla, calda, piccola e bella.Come tutte le città attraversate da corsi d'acqua ha un'atmosfera particolare.L'unica cosa "strana" è che per i mezzi pubblici non ci sono abbonamenti turistici ed ogni biglietto (1,40€) vale una sola corsa...mh!
Sevilla es una de las mejores ciudades de España. me gustó mucho el ambiente, sus monumentos, la temperatura y en general sus calles y plazas. Es una ciudad para visitar en cualquier época del año.
Città sorprendente e piena di attrattive, il Real alcazar lascia senza fiato. La Macarena la parte che mi ha meno entusiasmato
les bars à tapas, le promenade le long du fleuve, la beauté des monuments, les orangers en fleurs!!!

column2: “Esta ciudad siempre es maravillosa, excepto en julio y agosto”
column3: Me encantó el barrio de Santa Cruz, la Catedral, la Plaza de España. Los jardines de Murillo....Hay que hacer una visita al barrio de Triana y un pequeño paseo por el Guadalquivir. También el paseo en calesa por el centro es muy agradable.

È uma cidade muito interessante, alegre e principalmente histórica. O centro histórico é muito interessante com as influências muçulmanas e cristãs. O parque Maria Luisa é muito bonito e merece uma visita. Não perca um show com a dança flamenca.
Berço do flamenco, esta cidade é maravilhosa. Quem vai a Espanha, tem que conhecer. A vida noturna é encantadora e os vários tablaos de dança flamenca são imperdíveis.
es bonita y cómoda de visitar.su olor, gentes, bares, comida, cultura....todo es perfectooo. es importante reservar los hoteles con antelacion por su altas reservas, pero por lo demas estupendooo

Sin duda una de las ciudades más bellas de Europa; muchísimos rincones con encanto y monumentos impresionantemente bellos como la Plaza de España, La Catedral, La Giralda, Los Alcazares...etc; recomiendo visitarla en primavera (no en semana santa); ciudad con muy buen clima que invita a pasear y al tapeo.
Não deixe de visitar o Alcazar - e reserve tempo para passear pelos jardins - a Catedral e os Arquivos das índias.
Cidade alegre e vibrante, lugares majestosos, povo alegre e que gosta de "ir as tapas". Só elogios. Vi um show de flamenco muito bom. Muitos lugares para conhecer e andar pela cidade é uma festa.
Sevilla, con su olor a azahar, sus calles, sus gentes, su río Guadalquivir y las terrazas, En fin, dar un paseo por Sevilla, ya sea de noche o de día, es algo especial
Temiz ve bakımlı bahçeler ve caddeler görülmesi gerekli .Bizim gezimiz kısa zamanda çok yer görmek idi. Ama Sevillaya zaman ayırmak gerek.Eski binalar çok iyi korunmuş.Etraf çiçeklerle donanmış idi.
Einfach Sevilla mit Palästen, schönen Plätzen und Parks und den Gassen. Stadtrundfahrt für den ersten Eindruck.

La gente, el color, el olor, sus calles, Triana, la plaza de Dª Elvira, La Maestranza, la calle Betis, La Plaza de España, mejor seria decir que no megusto... que por cierto creo que no hubo nada que no me gustara.
mi è piaciuto tutto peccato esserci stata così poco , visitata la città con l'autobus turistico, con fermate ad ogni luogo di interesse, tipo la plaza de espana

Pour découvrir SEVILLE, l'offre SIGHTSEEING est intéressante.Il y a beaucoup de choses à voir et deux grandes journées nous ont laissé sur notre "faim" !Que dire des très nombreux orangers qui bordent les avenues et qui embaument !
Muy agradable de visitar, accesible clima espectacular muy bien el Guadalquivir para hacer deporte y muy simpáticos todos

non ho altro da aggiungere..avevo grandi attese e non sono state deluse.E' una città unica , dalla grande atmosfera, bellissimi monumenti, arte moderna fusa con edifici storici, grande cucina.... insomma ci tornerei subito...

column2: “Una ciudad que siempre merece la pena”
column3: Sevilla nunca decepciona, se visite cuantas veces se quiera siempre merece la pena. Tapeo espectacular. Y un paseo por el centro siempre es reconfortante.

column2: “città piena di vita ma a misura d'uomo”
column3: bellissima, ci tornerei volentieri, vicoli e viuzze che di distrivano per la Giuderia fino ad arrivare all' imponente Cattedrale e all'alcazar(Palazzo Reale) locali lungo il Guadalquivir, e tatnte tapas. Viva Espana... Viva Sevilla!

Una ciudad de las más bonitas de España sin duda, la Giralda, Catedral, Alcazar, el barrio de Santa cruz, etc. Es una cuidad grande pero sin exceso, puedes ir andando a la mayoria de las partes del centro. Si estas lejos del centro, hay metro y autobuses. Se come de categoría y la gente es encantadora.

Une ville tout simplement magnifique avec une architecture très riche, des maisons plus belles les unes que les autres, la gentillesse des espagnoles et des monuments hors du commun. Les jardins sont agréables, il est possible de varier vos activités. A noter le bel effort effectué par les Espagnols pour inciter les gens à visiter les musées avec très souvent une gratuité le lundi. Ajouter à cela le fait que certaines compagnies (Easyjet pour ne pas la citer) qui propose des tarifs très intéressants au départ d'aéroport comme Genève par exemple et cela incite réellement à visiter de belles villes comme celle-ci. Cordou est à une heure en train (à visiter également). La période actuelle est idéale car moins chaude qu'en Mai, Juin... A noter que beaucoup de visites sont proposées en Français (arenes par exemple) et les cartes des restaurants sont très souvent en Français également. Bonne visite.
Nous avons tout apprécié dans cette ville les monuments, les jardins, les restos, l'ambiance, le mélange des cultures. A refaire plus longuement car deux jours c'est un peu court.

perdersi senza meta tra le vie e viuzze del centro storico è una esperienza bellissima. Città ricca di monumenti , di attrazioni spettacolari e funzionale con le piste ciclabili e le bici pubbliche accessibili in una miriade di punti e parcheggi.La consiglio sia come meta di un fine settimana prolungato sia come punto di partenza per esplorare l'aldalusia
Una ciudad para recorrer y admirar, con multitud de rincones con encanto. Preferible visitarla en primavera u otoño

cada vez que visito Sevilla me enamoro mas de ellatiene todas las ventajas de una gran ciudad con la suerte de no llegar ni al millón de habitantessu luz, los naranjos, el río, el parque de Maria Luisa, la Catedral y la Giralda, el barrio de Santa Cruz, el puente de Triana, la lista de lugares en los que pasar horas y horas observando y disfrutando es interminablesoy de Madrid y tengo envidia, mucha envidiacomo decía Antonio Gala "Lo malo no es que los sevillanos piensen que tiene la ciudad más bonita del mundo... lo peor es que puede que tengan hasta razón."

Città stupenda, molti i monumenti da visitare, ricca di storia, bello il fiume. La popolazione e' molto cordiale e gioiosa. Ci sono molti locali carini... Credo di tornare per visitare ciò che non sono riuscito a visitare

Mancavo da Sevilla da diversi anni, e l'ho ritrovata ancora più bella e curata! Tra la cattedrale, il barrio di Santa Cruz, il Parasol Mirador.. è sicuramente una delle città più belle e vere della Spagna!
Мои впечатления от посещения Севильи можно выразить одним словом -ПРЕВОСХОДНО!!! Город понравится страстным любителям архитектурного зодчества своим великолепием и разнообразием стилей.
Bueno Sevilla es algo unico. Su color, su OLOR, sus calles, casco historico, en fin, un conjunto que abruma de manera sobrenatural al visitante. Una de esas ciudades que tienes que visitar, SIN DUDA.

Pasear por Sevilla y disfrutar de sus bares, su comida y su gente es un tópico que se convierte en realidad cuando dedicas unas días a descubrirla. En cualquiera de sus facetas ( cultural, histórica, ocio, gastronómica....) merece,y mucho, la pena!!
No hay un rincon de la ciudad que no sea visitable. Gente y clima inigualable (excepto meses de verano)

Prachtige stad,met veel tegeltjes,plaza Espana in het Maria luisa park is een must.overal gezelligheid,buiten lang lunchen met heerlijke tapas.De wijk Santa cruz is een doolhof van kleine straatjes met overal pleintjes.Het enige wat opviel was dat de Spanjaarden zo slecht of helemaal geem engels spreken.jong en oud maakt niet uit.maar ja alle films worden nagesynchroniseerd.

Были в Севильи 3 дня. Это 3 дня сказки! Какая же красавица - Севилья с аллеями их апельсиновых, лимонных деревьев. С великолепными роскошными соборами, памятниками, фонтанами и своей древней историей. Это город Дон Жуана и Колумба. Кафедральный собор - один из крупнейших и красивейших христианских соборов в мире. Великолепно прокатиться на повозке по старинным улочкам Севильи!

Não pensava que Sevilha fosse tão bela e bem cuidada. A magnifíca Plaza de Espanha, o centro histórico, catedral, a Plaza Mayor, o Metropol Parasol, Plaza de Toros, El Patio Sevilhano, Universidade, museus, andar pelas margens do rio Guadalquivir, o estilo arquitetonico Andaluz, os azulejos e pinturas nas fachadas, mas principalmente o incrível Palacio Real Alcazar e seus jardins. Imperdível.
Centro de Sevilha espetacular Igreja Maravilhosa, cidade movimentada tanto durante o dia, como no período noturno.
Sevilha me capturou pela simpatia de seu povo, pelas delícias de sua culinária, e pela beleza de seus atrativos.Quero retornar breve!
Très belle ville aux habitants sympathiques.Plein de choses a voir.La place d'espoagne, l'alcazar, le quartier de santa cruz et les archives des indes sont absoluments a voir.

Sevilha é história pura. Se mantém o orgulho de ser parte romana (Itálica), parte moura (Ishbilia) e origem da Espanha (Spagna). Todas as arquiteturas se misturam. A Catedral é a maior de estilo gótico no mundo e contém o corpo de Cristóvão Colombo. O arquivo das índias é o mesmo de onde saiam as grandes navegações do séc XV, incrível museu. Não tenha dúvidas, patrimônio de toda cultura ocidental, latino-americana e mundial. Visite o quanto antes.
3 giorni da passare a siviglia li merita veramente. ottime le offerte aeree e i prezzi per mangiare (paiella e tapas) le persone sono educate e gentili

column2: “buen clima , se puede pasear con tranquilidad”
column3: barrio santa cruz , catedral , archivo de indias , museo de bellas artes , cubiertas de la catedral , el salvador ,
Monumentos históricos y arqueológicos en buen estado de conservación, gente muy cálida, excelente comida. Vale la pena ir
Sevilla es una ciudad maravillosa, sus calles serpenteantes, los naranjos, los balcones, las fachas, el flamenco y su adorable gente.

Sevilha me fascinou... muito bela... encantadora! Tem uma magia simples e gitana! O flamenco é de uma pureza e encantamento incríveis. Pura passión! As praças são belas com arquitetura em linhas curvas.
Perderse por sus calles, visitar los monumentos, comer y beber en sus restaurantes y tasca y hablar con sus gentes , es la esencia misma de la buena vida.
C'est une ville pleine d histoire et de charme!! le soleil y brille toute l année et les rues sont pleine de vie!!
Zowel vele monumenten te bezoeken als heerlijke parken. Winkelen, relaxen, heerlijk eten tegen billijke prijzen. Geweldige leuke ervaring!

Sevilla is een geweldige stad om te voet te verkennen. Alle bezienswaardigheden liggen op loop afstand rondom het centrum. De eerste dag zijn we met de Hop on hop off geweest. Je hebt dan snel een beeld van de stad.

column2: “Espectacular catedral e inigualable la Real Maestranza de Sevilla”
column3: Es una bellisima ciudad que por lo menos debes dedicarle tres dias,no puedes dejar de recorrer la plaza españa,la plaza de toros Real Maestranza,el barrio de Triana,la Torre de oro,el puente de calatrava,el barrio de la macarena,y los callejones del centro histórico,solo por decir algo de lo mucho que se puede vivir en ese lugar

Hola carissimi,Per gli amanti della Spagna e per chi ancora non sa di esserlo,quale buona occasione per diventarlo ,esplorando la magnifica Sevilla?Siviglia è senza dubbio il cuore dell'Andalusia ,è la città delle Donne e delle arance ,delle tradizioni e del flamenco ed è visitabile in pochi giorni(3 giorni) a piedi.Per quanto riguarda l'albergo vi consiglio di soggiornare nell'hotel LA GIRALDA in calle Abades,centralissimo e confortevole,a due passi dalle principali attrazioni.Cattedrale e Alcazar consiglio di visitarle con una guida locale(che troverete al'entrata della cattedrale) ,molto più utile di un audioguida.Caratteristico è il Barrio de Santa Cruz,antico ghetto ebraico,con le sue stradine strette e i locali andalusi perfetti per "andare di Tapas"(piccoli assaggi a pochi euro) e per concedersi un vero flamenco ,lontano dai circuiti turistici,la Carboneria rappresenta tutto ciò che cercate: spettacolo gratis e consumazione obbligatoria economica.Appena fuori le mura,da segnalare:l'entrata alla plaza de toros con il caratteristico museo e il giardino di Maria luisa adiacente alla bellissima Plaza de espana.Non posso dimenticare il calore, i colori ma sopratutto i rintocchi della maestosa Cattedrale accompagnati dal ritmo delle antiche ballate suonate dalle chitarre di artisti per strada.Periodo consigliato settimana santaperiodo sconsigliato :estate per le elevate temperatureNB: gli studenti beneficiano di sconti nei musei solo mostrando documenti che ne attestino lo stato.

column2: “Een prachtige stad met veel mooie bezienswaardigheden”
column3: Als je redelijk ter been bent liggen al die bezienswaardigheden op loopafstand en alles is vlak. Ook wandelen door de centrum straten is mooi. Het is/lijkt een rijke/luxe stad. Zeker de moeite waard en één dag is eigenlijk te kort.
Tutto bello , sembra piccola 700.000 abitanti ma ci sono moltissime cose da vedere . Comodo con l aeroporto (abbiamo volato con Rayanair ) moltissimo da vedere e anche il fiume guadalquavir

Es una ciudad con muchísimas cosas que ver; la catedral, la giralda, el alcazar, la maestranza, la torre del oro y sus calles llenas de ambiente. Me ha gustado mucho, en mi opinión la ciudad más completa de Andalucía.

Maravillosa ciudad para visitar y pasear por sus calles. Siempre está animada de gente. Es alegre y monumental.El carril bici es desconcertante, no hay quien se aclare entre otras cosas porque nadie lo respeta, ciclistas y peatones.A destacar el servicio en bares y restaurantes, lento y pausado.

In questa città si respira un'aria di festa e di giovialità.Girare a piedi è un vero piacere ogni angolo nasconde scorci accattivanti e locali che ti invitano ad entrare per godere di ambienti che variano tra il tradizionale ed il moderno.Il mescolare i pedoni alle bici e ai tram a prima vista sembra una follia, ma ti accorgi che è una mescolanza che funziona alla perfezione.

Une ville où on se sent bien, des quartiers de multiples influences, des sites rapprochés pour s'y balader à pied ou en vélo. Des sévillans très gentils, prêts à rendre service ou vous renseigner.Un climat très doux en février pour ceux qui craindraient la chaleur.
la città ricca di monumenti e storia è riuscita a valorizzare ulteriormente, con pulizia e cordialità quasi ovunque, un patrimonio splendido.
Гуляли вечером по узеньким улицам центральной части города. Здания и церкви красиво подсвечены. Вечерние улицы полны романтики. А какие витрины со свадебными платьями!
Sevilla encanta pelo seu charme próprio, uma cidade pequena com cara de metrópole, respirando arte e cultura. Com uma forte influencia árabe, Sevilla tem aspectos muito próprios que a definem.

column2: “Uma cidade com a cara da Espanha”
column3: Sevilha é quente linda e sacra.Sua catedral é inesplicável,a praça de Espanha deve ser percorrida de ponta a ponta para que cada detalhe de seus azulejos sejam percebidos.O Bairro Santa Cruz é para você se perder em suas ruelas com suas casas brancas e trepadeiras com flores grená.Suas igrejas apresentam virgens de uma beleza indescritíveis em tamanho natural.Se tiver a oportunidade de ver ,como eu, uma ´procissão v ai me entender

un endroit magnifique, raffiné, en particulier le palais arabe, avec ses patios qui inspire la paix et la sérénité, ses fontaines où le temps se suspens, ses azulejos qui décorent chaque mur d'une richesse de couleurs, ses jardins où les oiseaux font des concerts pour enrichir la beauté des images. à voir comme un avant goût de l'Alhambra de Grenade. car si on le voit après l'enchantement est moindre, puisqu'on atteint la perfection à Grenade... mais si l'on ne peut aller à Grenade, alors oui, il faut voir l'Alcazar de Séville, et prendre son temps se laisser imprégner par cette beauté.
Es un lugar que tienen que ver al pasar por España, no lo dejen pasar. Todo es bonito, la gente en lo particular me trato bien.
A cidade é muito bonita e além do aspecto histórico, ainda conta com lindas laranjeiras espalhadas por toda cidade. Belíssima paisagem!
Sevilha é uma surpresa magnifica. Uma cidade grande , cheia de historia e uma vida agitada e rica em cultura e gastronomia.

Si uno busca conocer la ciudad, pasear y hacer turismo, necesariamente debe visitar el centro de la ciudad. Es antiguo, pero lleno de historia y de atracciones. Uno puede caminar desde la catedral hasta la plaza nueva, y luego salir hasta el río Guadalquivir y visitar la torre del oro. El único "inconveniente" es el calor, que puede llegar a superar los 42 grados en verano, y caminar bajo el sol es complicado. En la noche también es posible hacer los paseos. Se recomienda visitar los bares de flamenco que se pagan "pasando la gorra", puesto que son muy baratos y ofrecen un espectáculo emotivo. Si uno viaja en pareja, es recomendable el paseo por el río Guadalquivir en el atardecer, ya sea por el puente o en barquito.

Посетил почти все крупные города Испании. Севилья не поразила. Bus turistic не рекомендую, кроме самого центра, который можно пройти пешком, смотреть особо нечего. От такого большого города ожидал большего, но центр очень хорош. Советую залезть на верх центрального собора. Очень красивый вид.

Me ha encantado el viaje a Sevilla, a la vez que disfrutado mucho de Triana también he conocido muchas cosas que me sonaban pero que desconocía y la visita guiada por Santiago de Pancho Tours fue muy interesante;)

Es una de esas ciudades que hay que visitar una vez en tu vida, repetirás. Entorno a la Catedral, monumentos, Plaza de la Alfalfa, Alameda, magnífica gastronomía, compras estupendas y muy buena relación calidad-precio.

Abbiamo visitato siviglia nel mese di febbraio, clima ideale, con una massima di quasi 20 gradi. Bellissime le stradine del barrio di s.ta cruz piene di localini caratteristici dove mangiare tapas e bere vino tinto de Verano! Da vedere assolutamente plaza de Espana!
lindas avenidas, largas e arborizadas, ruas limpas e arvores frutiferas em abundancia pela cidade. todos desfrutam de seus parques junto as familias, muitas crianças e um colorido fantastico.

E' la quarta città della Spagna che visito, dopo Madrid, Barcellona e Valencia, ma non pensavo che fosse quella che più mi potesse colpire. E' un luogo dove antico e moderno si fondono, così come i vari stili degli edifici, contaminati dalla lontanissima dominazione araba. E' una città "meridionale", dunque vitale, gioiosa, calda con attenzione al cibo, al folklore (che dire degli spettacoli di flamenco e i ventagli meravigliosi!!). Ma l'ho trovata anche pulita e sicura. Con 100€ di biglietto A/R Ryanair, ho potuto conoscere una città straordinaria. Visitatela, se potete, e non vi deluderà.

Como es nuestra costumbre junto a mi esposa; siempre planificamos nuestro viaje con antelación y a sabiendas que deberemos alojarnos en un lugar como en este caso dentro del casco histórico y que mejor que en el Barrio de Santa Cruz. Así lo hicimos. En consecuencia la caminamos con un mapa en la mano a nuestro ritmo y sin apuro; deleitándonos y sorprendiéndonos en cada uno de nuestros itinerarios con la singular magia de esta maravillosa e histórica Ciudad.

Nå er vel de fleste større spanske byer like når det gjelder gamlebyen, og det gjelder vel også for gamlebyen i Sevilla. Men Sevilla har store parker og fantasiske bygninger spredd utover et stort område. Byen er rik på historie også fra vår nære fortid. Vi til en byrundfart med det røde selskapet. Originalen. Men vår opplevelse var meget dårlig. Sjåføren hadde det travelt hele tiden og vi satt ganske forvirret om kommentarene i øretelefonene lå til høyre, rett fram eller til venstre. Plutselig skulle de ha service på bussen og vi ventet i 20 min før turen fortsatte. På fortauet sto sjåføren og fire andre rødkledde og røyket, pratet og lo. Det virket som de ikke hadde sett hverandre på en stund. Så fortsatte turen i et ennå høyere tempo. Sjåførene snakket ikke engelsk, og de forsto heller intet. Velg heller det GRØNNE alternativet.
bonita cidade e fácil de conhecer, seja a pé ou de bicicleta.os pontos turisticos são proximos e o fato de a cidade ser plana convida a passear pelas ruas

Difficile dire cosa è piaciuto di più!Dalla fusione dell'arte tra occidente e mondo islamico, dalla gente cordiale e serena; le tapas!!!!!!!!! il Flamenko!!!!! il Tinto de Verano!!! e tanto tanto altro!!!

Sevilha é uma cidade cheia de bares e restaurantes, onde é possível apreciar as famosas tapas. A feira de Abril e a Semana Santa são as atividades mais importantes e vale a pena conhecer. A cidade tem muitas atrações turísticas, como a praça de Espanha, a Giralda, o bairro de Triana e o bairro de Santa Cruz. A partir dela é possível conhecer muitas outras cidades das redondezas. O período de julho-agosto é muito quente, motivo pelo qual não recomendo a visita nesses meses.

Sevilla hay q conoser la en Semana Santa y feria en cuando esta sevilla presioso unn perfecto paseo x las calles sevillana o si lo prefiere pasear xbla feria y degustar su gastronomía asin comk su rebujito jajaj..
lo mejor, el centro, monumentos, barrio santa cruz, el olor a azahar en primavera. Lo peor, los restaurantes para turistas.

Esta ciudad estimula todos los sentidos. Se necesitan varios días para recorrerla a fondo. Estuve dos días enteros caminando de las 7 de la mañana hasta pasada la medianoche.Todo es BELLÍSIMO. Sus edificios emblemáticos, los barrios de Triana y Santa Cruz, la Plaza España, los Jardines de María Luisa, los puentes sobre el Guadalquivir. Cada calle, cada rinconcito, cada plaza deslumbra con un encanto particular.El alma se carga de espíritu sevillano a cada paso.

column2: “Visitar Sevilla en Enero fue una buena opción”
column3: Es la segunda vez que visito Sevilla en Enero, tuvimos un tiempo estupendo, un poco de frío pero nada comparado con el norte de España. Hay pocos turistas por tanto se pueden hacer las visitas a los monumentos sin aglomeraciones y sin esperar cola. Lo mismo para callejear por la zona histórica, poca gente y se pasea muy tranquilo. Las tabernas y restaurantes de tapas están llenas de gente local y el ambiente resulta muy auténtico.

Ya lo dice la canción "Sevilla tiene un color especial". Ciudad que nunca te cansarás de visitar porque siempre hay algo nuevo por ver o recordar. La he visitado en dos ocasiones y aún no la conozco completamente. Destacaría además de su Catedral, la Torre del Oro y el puente de Triana, además de sus barrios de Triana y Santa Cruz, como puntos de visita obligada, además de numerosísimas iglesias, llenas de arte y tradición, donde podrás encontrar innumerables ejemplos de escultura barroca y pasos procesionales.

column2: “Sevilla, ciudad unica y romantica. La Paris del sur de Europa”
column3: Ciudad encantandora y realmente bonita. Facil de conocer atraves de sus habitantes que la muestran a los visitantes orgullosos de sus costumbres y sus artes. Es facil conocer gente en un bar y acabar teniendo amigos en una de las ciudades mas acogedoras en la que he estado.
gostei de tudo o que vi , a cidade nos transmite aconhego a sua catedral tanto no interior e exterior vale a pena visitar as ruas sao cheias de arvores com frutas
Gostei das avenidas largas e arborizadas, da limpeza das ruas, dos Espanhóis desfrutando da cidade ,dos parques e das inúmeras atrações turísticas. Não gostei dos acharcadores de turistas
Abbiamo girato per 4 giorni piacevolmente, c'è tantisimo da vedere e il clima festoso coinvolge. E poi era solo l'epifania, non oso pensare per la semana santa o la feria de avril.

Estuvimos en enero y la verdad es que nos encantó pero tuvimos mala suerte con el tiempo pues aunque hizo buena temperatura llovió bastante.Mucha animación y ambiente en todos los rinconesMuchas cosas para ver. Un viaje recomendable para ir en fMilia
Van alle steden in Spanje scoort deze stad bij ons zeer goed, dus ga daar eens genieten van de mooie gebouwen, de flamenco en de vele tapas restaurantjes!
